[Exam: Part 2 2021] Calpainopathy (LGMD2A) is an autosomal recessive limb‐girdle muscular dystrophy caused by CAPN3 mutations. It classically presents with:
• Progressive pelvic and shoulder girdle weakness leading to scapular winging.
• Markedly elevated serum creatine kinase (often >10× normal).
• Muscle biopsy showing dystrophic features (fiber necrosis, regeneration, endomysial fibrosis) with only lymphocytic inflammation.
Distinguishing dystrophic from inflammatory myopathies relies on clinical distribution, CK elevation magnitude, and specific histopathology.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Calpainopathy’s presentation—scapular winging, early hip girdle involvement, and hyperCKemia (5,000–15,000 U/L)—is well‐established (Murphy et al., Neurology 2015). While muscle biopsy may demonstrate minor inflammatory infiltrates, prominent eosinophils are atypical and represent a red herring, often pointing toward parasitic or eosinophilic myositis. Definitive diagnosis requires demonstrating calpain‐3 deficiency via immunoblot or identifying CAPN3 mutations on a targeted genetic panel. The ENMC 2018 consensus recommends a stepwise approach: CK measurement → muscle MRI → immunohistochemistry for LGMD proteins → genetic testing. In contrast, dermatomyositis and polymyositis show distinct immune cell patterns and respond to immunosuppression, which is ineffective in dystrophies.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Dermatomyositis: Presents with heliotrope rash, Gottron papules, perivascular B-cell and CD4+ T-cell infiltrates, complement-mediated microangiopathy; biopsy reveals perimysial inflammation—not dystrophic necrosis—and CK is only moderately elevated.
C. Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy: Autosomal dominant D4Z4 contraction leading to facial and scapular muscle involvement; CK is normal or mildly elevated; biopsy shows mild fiber size variability without significant necrosis or eosinophils.
D. Polymyositis: Adult-onset proximal muscle weakness with endomysial CD8+ T-cell infiltration and moderate CK elevation; lacks early scapular winging and eosinophilic infiltrates; immunosuppressive therapy is effective.

• Always exclude genetic myopathies via imaging and immunohistochemistry before initiating immunosuppressive therapy.

• Attributing scapular winging to long thoracic nerve palsy without assessing for proximal muscle weakness and CK levels.
• Administering steroids in undiagnosed dystrophies, risking steroid myopathy without benefit.

- ENMC 2018 Workshop on LGMD: Recommends diagnostic algorithm—CK assay → MRI → immunohistochemistry for sarcolemmal proteins → CAPN3 genetic panel; expert consensus, Level C.
• EULAR/ACR 2017 Classification Criteria for Idiopathic Inflammatory Myopathies: Defines inflammatory myopathy subtypes by clinical, serologic, and histopathologic features; stresses exclusion of genetic dystrophies before applying myositis criteria; Level B evidence.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Compression or traction of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8–T1) during axillary dissection can present as ulnar‐territory symptoms (4th/5th digit dysesthesia). Key principles:
1. Brachial plexus anatomy—roots C5–T1 form trunks; the lower trunk gives rise to fibers destined for the ulnar nerve.
2. Postsurgical neuropathy—traction, fibrosis or direct nerve injury can produce demyelination or axonal loss, manifesting as sensory changes.
3. Electrodiagnostic confirmation—nerve conduction studies (NCS) with EMG localize lesions, differentiate demyelination vs axonal injury, and guide prognosis and further therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

NCS/EMG is the gold standard for evaluating suspected brachial plexopathies (AANEM practice guideline, 2021). Early electrodiagnostic studies (ideally 2–3 weeks post-injury to capture Wallerian degeneration) allow:
• Localization of lesion within the plexus or peripheral nerve
• Characterization of injury type (demyelinating vs axonal)
• Severity grading that informs the need for surgical exploration versus conservative care (Carr et al., J Neurosurg 2019).

Randomized data (Smith et al., Muscle Nerve 2022) show that timely electrodiagnosis reduces time to definitive management and improves functional outcomes. Without NCS/EMG, therapy is blind to lesion site and may delay appropriate intervention.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Physical therapy
• Why incorrect: PT without localization may exacerbate injury or miss a compressive etiology.
• Misconception: “Just move it and it will heal.”
• Differentiator: PT is supportive, not diagnostic.

C. Pain management
• Why incorrect: Analgesics or neuropathic agents address symptoms but not lesion characterization.
• Misconception: “Treat symptoms first, then diagnose.”
• Differentiator: Symptom control is adjunctive, not primary diagnostic step.

D. Surgical intervention
• Why incorrect: Exploration or decompression without electrodiagnostic confirmation risks unnecessary surgery.
• Misconception: “Postoperative nerve pain always needs early exploration.”
• Differentiator: Surgery is reserved for severe axonal lesions proven by electrodiagnosis.

- Post-mastectomy neuropathy in the 4th/5th digits often implicates lower trunk/ulnar fibers, not intercostobrachial nerve.
• Optimal timing for EMG/NCS is 2–3 weeks post-injury to detect fibrillations from Wallerian degeneration.
• Early electrodiagnosis can distinguish demyelinating injuries (which may recover conservatively) from severe axonal loss requiring surgery.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing intercostobrachial neuralgia (medial brachial cutaneous) with ulnar neuropathy—check dermatome map (intercostal T2–T3).
2. Initiating therapy (PT or surgery) before establishing lesion site and severity—delays targeted management.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Association of Neuromuscular & Electrodiagnostic Medicine (AANEM) Practice Guideline, 2021: Recommends NCS/EMG for all suspected plexopathies to guide management (Level B evidence).
• European Neuromuscular Centre (ENMC) Consensus Statement, 2020: Advises electrodiagnostic evaluation at 2–3 weeks post-injury for accurate axonal degeneration assessment (Strength of Recommendation: Grade II).
• Smith et al., Muscle Nerve 2022 (RCT): Early electrodiagnosis (within 3 weeks) reduced time to definitive therapy by 30% and improved 6-month functional scores (p<0.01).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Roots C8–T1 converge to form the lower trunk, giving rise to medial cord and the ulnar nerve.
• Ulnar nerve travels posterior to the medial epicondyle and through Guyon’s canal, supplying sensation to digits 4–5 and intrinsic hand muscles.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Traction or compression during axillary dissection causes focal demyelination (conduction block) or axonal loss (Wallerian degeneration).
• Degree of injury (Seddon’s neuropraxia vs axonotmesis) predicts recovery: demyelinating injuries recover in weeks, axonal injuries months.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed history (timing, surgery details).
2. Focused exam (dermatomes, motor testing).
3. Baseline imaging (ultrasound/MRI if mass suspected).
4. NCS/EMG at 2–3 weeks post-onset.
5. Follow-up studies for progression; surgical referral if severe axonal loss.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI of the brachial plexus can detect edema, T2 hyperintensity in acute plexitis, or scarring in chronic injury.
• High-resolution ultrasound may visualize nerve continuity and guide injections.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Neuropathic pain agents (gabapentin 300 mg TID titrated to effect; duloxetine 30 mg daily) provide symptom relief while diagnostic workup is underway.
• Avoid masking progression that would alter surgical decision-making.

[Exam: Part I 2019] Hereditary Neuropathy with Liability to Pressure Palsies (HNPP) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by deletion of the PMP22 gene on chromosome 17. Core concepts:
• PMP22 protein is essential for compact myelin sheath integrity.
• Tomacula are focal “sausage‐like” myelin thickenings pathognomonic for HNPP.
• Clinically, patients present with transient focal neuropathies at common entrapment sites (e.g., peroneal, ulnar).

(Word count: ~85)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The defining histopathological feature in HNPP is tomacula—focal hypermyelination with redundant loops of myelin—resulting from unstable compact myelin due to reduced PMP22 dosage. Bird et al. (Neurology, 1993) first characterized tomacula in PMP22-deleted nerves; subsequent series (Sprecher et al., Brain, 2001; Li et al., J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry, 2015) report tomacula in >80% of sural biopsies. These myelin infoldings disrupt nodal architecture, causing conduction block. This is distinct from the diffuse demyelination seen in CMT1A (PMP22 duplication) or the primary axonal loss of hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy type II.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Axonal degeneration
• Incorrect: Axonal loss occurs secondarily in chronic demyelination, not primarily in HNPP.
• Misconception: Confusing HNPP with axonal neuropathies (e.g., diabetic, hereditary motor–sensory neuropathy II).
• Differentiator: Axonal degeneration shows fiber loss and axonal ovoids, without focal myelin sausage-shaped thickenings.

C. Demyelination of all nerve fibers
• Incorrect: HNPP shows segmental demyelination at pressure points, not uniform across all fibers.
• Misconception: Equating HNPP with generalized demyelinating neuropathies like CMT1.
• Differentiator: Tomacula are focal infoldings, not diffuse myelin loss.

D. Increased number of Schwann cells
• Incorrect: Schwann cell proliferation (onion bulbs) is characteristic of chronic inherited demyelination (CMT1), not HNPP.
• Misconception: Conflating any Schwann cell change with the tomacula of HNPP.
• Differentiator: Onion bulbs are concentric Schwann cell layers; tomacula are myelin folds.

Clinical Pearls

- HNPP often presents with transient focal mononeuropathies (e.g., foot drop after minor compression).
• Nerve conduction studies reveal conduction block at common entrapment sites with near‐normal conduction elsewhere.
• Genetic testing for PMP22 deletion confirms diagnosis in >95% and obviates need for biopsy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Misreading tomacula as onion bulbs; tomacula are myelin infoldings, onion bulbs are concentric Schwann cell proliferations.
• Skipping genetic testing and proceeding directly to biopsy; noninvasive genetic assays are more sensitive and specific.
• Assuming HNPP shows diffuse demyelination; pathology is segmental and focal.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The sural nerve is purely sensory, containing large myelinated fibers prone to pressure at the lateral malleolus. Tomacula form in these internodal regions due to focal myelin instability.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PMP22 deletion leads to insufficient compact myelin protein, causing Schwann cells to overfold myelin layers into tomacula. These myelin outfoldings disrupt nodal architecture and predispose to pressure‐induced conduction failure.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: recurrent focal neuropathies.
2. Nerve conduction studies: focal conduction block at entrapment sites.
3. Genetic testing: confirm PMP22 deletion.
4. Sural nerve biopsy (if genetic tests inconclusive): identify tomacula.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] • Neuromuscular junction physiology: acetylcholine release, receptor binding, endplate potential generation.
• Autoimmune pathophysiology: antibodies against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors (AChR) (or MuSK/LRP4) reduce safety factor for neuromuscular transmission.
• Electrophysiological testing:
– Single fiber EMG (SFEMG) measures “jitter” (variability in inter-potential intervals) and blocking at individual muscle-fiber pairs.
– Repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) detects decremental response at 2–3 Hz.
– Pharmacologic testing (edrophonium) transiently increases ACh at the endplate.
• Serologic assays detect AChR antibodies in ~85% of generalized MG, but sensitivity is lower in purely ocular MG.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Single fiber EMG is the most sensitive diagnostic test for MG, with reported sensitivities of 95–99% in generalized disease and 85–90% in purely ocular presentations. The American Academy of Neurology (AAN) practice parameters (2020 update) and the 2016 International Consensus Guidance for Management of Myasthenia Gravis both endorse SFEMG as the first-line electrophysiological test when MG is suspected (Level B evidence). SFEMG quantifies jitter and blocking, directly reflecting impaired safety factor at the motor endplate. RNS has a sensitivity of 50–75% depending on the muscle tested, and edrophonium testing yields transient improvement in ~80% but carries false negatives in mild cases and risks cholinergic side effects. AChR antibody assays, while highly specific, miss ~15% of generalized and ~50% of ocular MG.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Acetylcholine antibodies
– Although highly specific (≈98%), AChR-Ab assays lack sensitivity in ocular MG (~50%) and miss ~15% of generalized cases.
– Misconception: equating high specificity with high sensitivity; seronegative MG can be diagnosed only by electrophysiology.

C. Repetitive nerve stimulation
– Sensitivity 50–75% (best in proximal muscles); false negatives common in ocular or mild disease.
– Misconception: RNS is the most reliable EMG method; in fact, it underestimates subtle transmission defects.

D. Edrophonium (Tensilon) test
– Sensitivity ~80%; false negatives in mild/ocular MG; risk of bradycardia, bronchospasm, requiring atropine on hand.
– Misconception: that a positive pharmacologic test is gold standard; utility is limited by contraindications and operator interpretation.

Clinical Pearls

• SFEMG “jitter” is quantified as the standard deviation of time differences between two muscle fibers; >55 µs abnormal.
• In seronegative patients, test for MuSK and LRP4 antibodies, but SFEMG remains key.
• Test multiple muscles (e.g., frontalis, extensor digitorum) if initial SFEMG is equivocal, due to patchy NMJ involvement.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overrelying on serology: assuming a negative AChR-Ab rules out MG.
2. Misinterpreting a normal RNS as excluding MG, especially in ocular or mild generalized forms.
3. Failing to prepare for cholinergic crisis when performing edrophonium testing (have atropine at bedside).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Consensus Guidance for Myasthenia Gravis (2016): recommends SFEMG as first-line electrophysiological test in suspected MG (Level B).
2. European Academy of Neurology/European Federation of Neurological Societies MG Guidelines (2021): endorse SFEMG over RNS for highest diagnostic yield; advise antibody testing followed by SFEMG if seronegative (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The motor endplate is characterized by extensive postsynaptic folding and high-density ACh receptor clusters. In MG, autoantibody-mediated AChR loss and complement activation flatten junctional folds, reducing safety factor for depolarization.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoimmune antibodies (AChR, MuSK, LRP4) disrupt neuromuscular transmission by:
1. Direct receptor blockade.
2. Complement-mediated destruction of postsynaptic membrane.
3. Accelerated receptor internalization.
Resultant decreased endplate potential triggers jitter and blocking on SFEMG.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion (fluctuating fatigable weakness, ocular symptoms).
2. Serology: AChR-Ab → if negative test MuSK/LRP4.
3. Electrophysiology: SFEMG → if unavailable or equivocal, perform RNS.
4. Pharmacologic testing: edrophonium if diagnostic ambiguity remains.
5. Imaging (CT/MRI chest) for thymoma once diagnosis is established.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Peripheral neuropathies may be primary demyelinating disorders or secondary to systemic diseases. Key concepts:
1. Paraneoplastic neuropathy: immune-mediated nerve damage triggered by a plasma cell or lymphoid clone.
2. Monoclonal protein (M-protein) syndromes: an M-spike in serum/urine suggests plasma cell dyscrasia; type of light chain (λ vs κ) directs diagnosis.
3. Systemic “POEMS” features—Polyneuropathy, Organomegaly, Endocrinopathy, Monoclonal protein, Skin changes (edema, hyperpigmentation)—distinguish it from CIDP variants or pure muscular dystrophies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

POEMS syndrome is defined by mandatory polyneuropathy plus monoclonal plasma cell disorder (λ light chain) and ≥1 major (sclerotic bone lesions, Castleman disease, elevated VEGF) and ≥1 minor criterion (organomegaly, endocrinopathy, edema, skin changes). Dispenzieri et al. (Blood, 2014) and the International Myeloma Working Group (2019) confirm elevated VEGF levels drive vascular permeability, causing edema and neuropathy. CIDP lacks systemic organomegaly or M-protein; DADS (a distal CIDP variant) is associated with IgM anti-MAG antibodies, not λ chains or endocrinopathy. Miyoshi myopathy (dysferlinopathy) is a muscular dystrophy with elevated CPK, no monoclonal spike or organomegaly.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. CIDP
• Why incorrect: No monoclonal λ spike, organomegaly, or endocrinopathy.
• Misconception: All chronic demyelinating neuropathies are immune-mediated—CIDP is idiopathic, not paraneoplastic.

C. DADS
• Why incorrect: Characterized by distal sensory dysfunction with IgM anti-MAG antibodies, lacks λ chain, organomegaly, endocrine features.
• Misconception: Distal demyelination equals POEMS variant—DADS is a subset of CIDP without systemic signs.

D. Myoshi disease
• Why incorrect: Genetic dysferlin deficiency causes muscle weakness, high CPK, no neuropathy or M-protein.
• Misconception: “Myoshi” sounds like peripheral muscle disorder—this is muscular, not neuropathic.

Clinical Pearls

• Always screen for monoclonal proteins in unexplained neuropathy with systemic features.
• Measure VEGF: levels >200 pg/mL support POEMS and correlate with severity.
• First-line therapy is localized radiotherapy for solitary plasmacytoma; systemic lenalidomide/dexamethasone or bortezomib regimens for widespread disease.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing edema in neuropathy solely to steroids—POEMS edema is VEGF-mediated, often predating therapy.
2. Misdiagnosing POEMS as CIDP when M-spike screening is omitted.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• International Myeloma Working Group consensus (Blood, 2019): Diagnostic criteria for POEMS require polyneuropathy, λ-restricted M-protein, and ≥1 major and ≥1 minor feature (Level 2B).
• NCCN Guidelines for Multiple Myeloma (v4.2024): Recommend systemic therapy with lenalidomide + dexamethasone for POEMS with diffuse bone marrow involvement (Level 2A).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

A monoclonal λ plasma cell clone overproduces cytokines (VEGF, IL-6), increasing vascular permeability and causing edema, skin changes, and demyelinating neuropathy via endoneurial ischemia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm sensorimotor demyelinating neuropathy by EMG/NCS.
2. Screen serum/urine for M-protein and light-chain type.
3. Measure VEGF; evaluate for organomegaly, endocrinopathy, skin changes.
4. Perform bone marrow biopsy and skeletal imaging for sclerotic lesions.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Localized plasmacytoma: radiotherapy (40 Gy).
• Systemic disease: lenalidomide + dexamethasone or bortezomib-based induction, followed by autologous stem cell transplant if eligible.
• Neuropathic pain: gabapentin, duloxetine.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder of the neuromuscular junction. Key concepts:
• The neuromuscular junction relies on clustering of acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) by the agrin–LRP4–MuSK complex.
• Anti-MuSK MG involves IgG4 antibodies against muscle-specific tyrosine kinase (MuSK), disrupting AChR clustering without complement activation.
• Thymic pathology differs: anti-AChR MG often has thymic hyperplasia or thymoma, whereas anti-MuSK cases typically show a normal or atrophic thymus.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A is correct. Multiple clinicopathological series (Phillips et al., Ann Neurol 2003; Sanders et al., Neurology 2018) and the 2020 International Consensus Guidance on MG management report that anti-MuSK MG patients almost always have a normal or involuted thymus on histology, in contrast to the hyperplastic thymus or thymoma seen in anti-AChR MG. Anti-MuSK MG presents with bulbar, neck and respiratory weakness, rapid generalization, and poor response or paradoxical worsening with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (AChEIs). HLA associations differ (DR14-DQ5, not DRB8), and ocular-only presentations are uncommon. Current guidelines (Sanders et al., Muscle Nerve 2020) recommend immunosuppression—particularly rituximab—for MuSK-positive MG rather than relying on AChEIs.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Associated with HLA DRB8
• Incorrect: The strongest HLA link in MuSK MG is HLA-DR14-DQ5, not DRB8.
• Misconception: Extrapolating the DR3–B8–DQ2 haplotype from anti-AChR MG to MuSK MG.

C. Predominantly affects ocular muscles
• Incorrect: MuSK MG more often presents with bulbar and respiratory involvement; isolated ocular weakness is rare.
• Misconception: Equating all MG subtypes with ocular-predominant onset.

D. Responds well to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors
• Incorrect: Many MuSK MG patients have minimal benefit or cholinergic side effects with AChEIs; guidelines favor immunosuppressive agents.
• Misconception: Assuming all MG subtypes uniformly benefit from AChEIs.

- MuSK MG often requires early, aggressive immunotherapy (e.g., rituximab) due to rapid bulbar involvement and risk of crisis.
• Repetitive nerve stimulation in MuSK MG may show an initial incremental response after high-frequency stimulation, distinguishing it from AChR MG.
• Serum IgG4 subclass predominance in MuSK MG means complement inhibitors (e.g., eculizumab) are less effective than B-cell depletion strategies.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Equating anti-MuSK MG with thymic hyperplasia or thymoma, leading to unnecessary thymectomy.
• Overreliance on edrophonium or pyridostigmine response to diagnose MG subtype, ignoring MuSK-specific antibody testing.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Consensus Guidance for MG Management (Sanders DB et al., Muscle & Nerve 2020; Level C):
• Recommends rituximab as first-line immunotherapy in MuSK MG due to better sustained remission rates.
2. European Academy of Neurology MG Guidelines (Verschuuren JJ et al., Eur J Neurol 2021; Class II evidence):
• Emphasize genotyping HLA haplotypes for research; confirm normal thymic histology in MuSK cases before considering thymectomy.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Anti-MuSK IgG4 antibodies bind to MuSK on the postsynaptic membrane, blocking its interaction with LRP4 and agrin. Loss of MuSK signaling causes dispersal of AChRs, impairing neuromuscular transmission without complement-mediated destruction (Gilhus NE, Neurol Sci 2019).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: fatigable bulbar/respiratory weakness.
2. Serologic testing: anti-AChR antibodies → if negative, anti-MuSK antibodies.
3. Electrodiagnostics: high-frequency RNS or single-fiber EMG.
4. Imaging: chest CT/MRI for thymic pathology (expect normal/atrophic thymus).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Avoid high-dose AChEIs; monitor for cholinergic side effects.
• Initiate corticosteroids plus early rituximab for MuSK-positive patients.
• Consider azathioprine or mycophenolate mofetil as steroid-sparing agents.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Dysferlinopathy (Miyoshi myopathy/LGMD2B) is characterized by early involvement of distal posterior thigh and calf muscles with markedly elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels (often >20× normal).
Core concepts:
• Muscle membrane repair: Dysferlin is crucial for sarcolemmal resealing; its absence leads to myofiber necrosis and elevated CK.
• Topography of weakness: Distal-predominant weakness (calves, then hamstrings) contrasts with proximal-onset dystrophies.
• CK elevation: Levels >10–20× normal strongly suggest primary myopathy over neuropathy or inflammatory myositis.

(Word count: ~110)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dysferlinopathy results from autosomal recessive DYSF gene mutations leading to absent or dysfunctional dysferlin protein. Dysferlin mediates Ca²⁺-dependent membrane repair; its deficiency causes repeated myofiber injury, necrosis, and satellite cell–mediated regeneration, reflected by very high CK. Miyoshi myopathy variant presents in young adults with early calf and posterior thigh weakness, gait difficulties, and inability to plantar flex.
Current AAN practice parameters (2018) recommend:
• CK measurement as first-line in suspected myopathy.
• Muscle MRI to identify patterns (distal-predominant fatty infiltration).
• Confirmation with genetic testing or muscle biopsy demonstrating absent dysferlin on immunostaining.
A Phase I/II gene therapy trial (Coyle et al., Gene Ther 2022) showed safety of rAAV2/9-mediated dysferlin delivery, underscoring molecular diagnosis importance.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Becker muscular dystrophy
• Incorrect: X-linked, onset childhood-adolescence, primarily proximal pelvic–shoulder girdle, calf pseudohypertrophy; CK moderately elevated (5–10×).
• Misconception: Any calf weakness = dystrophinopathy—distinguished by pattern (proximal > distal).

C. Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease
• Incorrect: Hereditary sensorimotor neuropathy, presents with distal sensory loss, foot deformities, diminished reflexes; CK normal or mildly elevated.
• Misconception: Lower-limb weakness always myopathic—distinguish neuropathic via NCS (slowed conduction).

D. Inclusion body myositis
• Incorrect: Age >50, asymmetric finger flexor/quadriceps weakness, insidious course, modest CK elevation (<10×).
• Misconception: Any distal weakness = IBM—note age, inflammatory markers, muscle biopsy rimmed vacuoles.

2. European Neuromuscular Centre (ENMC) Dysferlinopathy Workshop Consensus (2022; Level C): endorses muscle biopsy immunostaining for dysferlin to guide AAV-mediated gene therapy eligibility.

DYSF gene mutations → defective sarcolemmal repair → persistent Ca²⁺ influx → calpain activation → myofiber necrosis → regeneration cycle → chronic myopathy and high CK release.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical: distal calf/hamstring weakness, gait difficulties
2. Laboratory: CK >10× normal
3. EMG: myopathic pattern
4. Muscle MRI: distal posterior involvement
5. Muscle biopsy: absent dysferlin on immunostain

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Muscle contraction relies on ATP generated via glycogenolysis, glycolysis, and oxidative phosphorylation.
• Myophosphorylase (encoded by PYGM) catalyzes the rate‐limiting step in glycogen breakdown in skeletal muscle.
• In McArdle disease (glycogen storage disease type V), myophosphorylase deficiency leads to intramuscular glycogen accumulation, early exercise‐induced cramps, and myoglobinuria.
• The “second‐wind” phenomenon reflects recruitment of blood‐borne fuels (glucose, free fatty acids) after ~7–10 minutes of exercise, improving performance.
• Neuromuscular junction disorders (myasthenia gravis, Lambert‐Eaton) feature fatigability but lack true second wind; Duchenne is a progressive dystrophy without exercise‐induced improvement.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Myophosphorylase deficiency is confirmed by:
1. Forearm ischemic exercise test – absent lactate rise, exaggerated ammonia increase (Campbell et al., Neurology 2019).
2. Genetic testing – biallelic PYGM mutations (Matzinger et al., Muscle Nerve 2020).
3. Muscle biopsy – subsarcolemmal glycogen vacuoles, absent enzyme activity.

Clinical management per the American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2020 Practice Guideline recommends:
• Pre‐exercise ingestion of simple carbohydrates to optimize blood glucose (Level B).
• Supervised aerobic training programs to enhance oxidative capacity (Level C).

Differentiation: no improvement after a few minutes of exertion occurs in MG or LEMS; DMD presents in early childhood with Gowers’ sign, not exercise‐related cramps.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Myasthenia gravis
• Why incorrect: Post‐exercise weakness worsens; no metabolic second wind.
• Misconception: Fatigability equals metabolic myopathy.
• Differentiator: MG shows decremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation, ocular ptosis.

C. Lambert-Eaton syndrome
• Why incorrect: Brief facilitation of strength with rapid contractions, not a sustained second wind.
• Misconception: All “improved with exercise” phenomena are metabolic.
• Differentiator: LEMS shows increment on high‐frequency stimulation, associated malignancy.

D. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
• Why incorrect: Progressive weakness from childhood, pseudohypertrophy, not exercise‐induced cramps or improvement.
• Misconception: All exercise-related weakness in youths is dystrophic.
• Differentiator: DMD has elevated CK >10× normal, dystrophin loss on immunohistochemistry.

• The “second‐wind” phenomenon is pathognomonic for McArdle disease and distinguishes it from NMJ disorders.
• Forearm ischemic exercise test remains the bedside screening tool for glycogen storage disease Type V.
• Pre‐exercise ingestion of 30 g sucrose 30 minutes before activity can ameliorate symptoms (ENMC Consensus, 2018).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing the facilitation in Lambert-Eaton syndrome with McArdle’s second wind—LEMS facilitation is transient (seconds), not sustained (minutes).
2. Assuming any exercise-induced weakness improving with rest is metabolic—MG may improve briefly at rest but worsens with repeated use.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Guideline, 2020
• Recommendation: Genetic testing (PYGM sequencing) and forearm exercise test for suspected McArdle disease (Level B).
2. European Neuromuscular Centre (ENMC) Consensus Statement, 2018
• Recommendation: Supervised aerobic training and pre‐exercise carbohydrate loading to enhance second wind (Level C).
3. UniQure Phase I/II Gene Therapy Trial, 2022
• Finding: AAV‐mediated PYGM delivery was safe and improved standardized cycle ergometry performance (Open‐label, Level II evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Myophosphorylase catalyzes release of glucose‐1‐phosphate from glycogen. Deficiency leads to:
• Glycogen accumulation in muscle fibers.
• Impaired anaerobic ATP production → early cramps and contractures.
• Compensatory upregulation of oxidative pathways accounts for second wind.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: exercise‐induced cramps, early fatigue, myoglobinuria.
2. Physical exam: normal strength at rest; cramps on exertion.
3. Forearm ischemic test: flat lactate curve, ammonia rise.
4. CK often elevated (500–2,000 IU/L).
5. Genetic confirmation: PYGM sequencing.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• No enzyme replacement available; management is dietary and rehabilitative.
• Pre‐exercise sucrose (30–40 g) to raise blood glucose.
• Supervised aerobic training to increase oxidative enzyme capacity.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Muscle disorders are classified into myopathic, neurogenic, and junctional etiologies. Limb-girdle muscular dystrophies (LGMD) comprise heterogeneous genetic myopathies primarily affecting the pelvic and shoulder girdles, leading to progressive proximal weakness. Onset typically occurs in childhood or adolescence, with autosomal recessive (e.g., sarcoglycanopathies) and autosomal dominant (e.g., laminopathies) inheritance patterns. Serum creatine kinase (CK) is markedly elevated (often >500 U/L), reflecting sarcolemmal instability. Characteristic features include a positive Gowers’ sign and preserved extraocular and bulbar strength. Distinguishing LGMD from inflammatory myopathies, neuromuscular junction disorders, and motor neuron diseases relies on family history, CK levels, EMG, muscle MRI, biopsy, and genetic testing.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy (LGMD) is the most likely diagnosis in this vignette. The 10-year history of slowly progressive, symmetric proximal weakness beginning in childhood, a positive family history among siblings, and a markedly elevated CK (2800 U/L) are classic for autosomal recessive LGMD subtypes (e.g., sarcoglycanopathies, calpain-3 deficiency). According to the 2018 European Neuromuscular Centre (ENMC) classification, LGMD is defined by onset after age 2, involvement of hip and shoulder girdles, and elevated CK due to sarcolemmal membrane defects (Straub et al., 2018).
Inflammatory myopathies (e.g., polymyositis, dermatomyositis) typically present subacutely over weeks to months, often in adults, with systemic features (rash, interstitial lung disease). Muscle biopsy demonstrates endomysial inflammatory infiltrates with CD8+ T-cells and upregulation of MHC-I, and patients usually respond to immunosuppression (Bohan & Peter, 1975).
Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) type III (Kugelberg-Welander) can present in childhood/adolescence but shows neurogenic EMG changes (fibrillations, large motor units) and normal or mildly elevated CK (∼200 U/L) due to denervation atrophy (Prior et al., 2009).
Myasthenia gravis presents with fluctuating weakness, ocular/bulbar involvement, fatigability on repetitive nerve stimulation, normal CK, and positive autoantibodies (MuSK, AChR) (Drachman, 1994).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Inflammatory myopathy
• Onset/subacute (<6 months), often adult; presents with rash (dermatomyositis) or systemic features.
• Biopsy: endomysial perimysial inflammation and MHC-I upregulation.
• CK typically elevated 1000–5000 U/L but family history is absent; immunosuppressive response expected.

C. Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA)
• Motor neuron disorder: EMG shows fibrillations, large‐amplitude motor units; CK is normal or mildly elevated (<300 U/L).
• Genetic testing identifies SMN1 deletions; sensory exam is preserved.

D. Myasthenia Gravis
• Autoimmune NMJ disorder: fluctuating, fatigable weakness with ocular/bulbar predominance; CK normal.
• Edrophonium test or repetitive nerve stimulation shows decrement; responds to cholinesterase inhibitors.

- Gowers’ sign (using hands on thighs to stand) is a sensitive indicator of proximal muscle weakness in LGMD.
• Asymptomatic individuals with CK >1000 U/L warrant evaluation for dystrophinopathies before immunosuppression.
• Muscle MRI revealing selective fatty infiltration of hip adductors and posterior thigh muscles helps target biopsy in LGMD.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking chronic familial myopathies for polymyositis can lead to unnecessary long‐term immunosuppression.
• Believing elevated CK excludes neurogenic disorders; mild CK elevations can be seen in chronic denervation (e.g., SMA).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- European Neuromuscular Centre (ENMC) LGMD Classification Workshop 2018: Recommends next-generation sequencing panels as first-line diagnostics for suspected LGMD to reduce invasive biopsies (Level IV, expert consensus).
• American Academy of Neurology 2020 Practice Guidelines on Genetic Testing in Neuromuscular Disorders: Advises gene panel testing over traditional biopsy in hereditary myopathies (Level B evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

LGMD subtypes result from mutations in genes encoding sarcolemmal or cytosolic proteins (e.g., α-, β-, γ-, δ-sarcoglycan; calpain-3; dysferlin). Loss of protein function compromises membrane stability or repair, leading to repeated cycles of myofiber necrosis, regeneration, fibrosis, and fatty replacement. The sarcoplasmic membrane leak causes CK leakage into circulation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed family and clinical history (onset, progression, distribution).
2. Physical exam: proximal weakness, Gowers’ sign, preserved ocular/bulbar function.
3. Laboratory: CK level quantification.
4. EMG: confirm myopathic pattern.
5. Muscle MRI: localize fatty infiltration.
6. Genetic testing: targeted LGMD gene panel.
7. Muscle biopsy: only if genetic results are nondiagnostic.

Neuroimaging Pearls

T1-weighted muscle MRI in LGMD shows a “fatty streak” predominantly in gluteus medius/minimus and posterior thigh compartments, unlike the diffuse edema seen in inflammatory myopathies.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- No FDA-approved disease-modifying drugs; management includes physical therapy, orthotics, and cardiac/respiratory monitoring.
• Emerging AAV-mediated gene therapies (e.g., for γ-sarcoglycan LGMD2C) are in early clinical trials, aiming to restore protein expression (Wein et al., 2023).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Proximal lower-limb weakness with a positive family history and high CK is a classic pattern for LGMD; testing typically emphasizes inheritance, CK magnitude, EMG findings, and the role of genetic diagnosis.

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder targeting neuromuscular junction components.
1. MuSK physiology: Muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase (MuSK) organizes acetylcholine receptor (AChR) clustering at the postsynaptic membrane.
2. Pathophysiology: Anti-MuSK antibodies disrupt MuSK‐Lrp4 interaction, leading to AChR dispersal and impaired synaptic transmission.
3. Clinical phenotype: Unlike AChR-positive MG, MuSK-MG features predominant bulbar (e.g., tongue, facial) and neck extensor weakness with early muscle atrophy; ocular signs (ptosis) are less common.
(Word count: 92)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Tongue weakness with atrophy is a hallmark of MuSK-MG. A 2021 MGFA guidance notes bulbar involvement in >70% of MuSK patients, often with visible muscle wasting (Jaretzki et al., 2021; Level B evidence). Unlike AChR-MG, ocular involvement is infrequent (<30%) (Somnier et al., 2019). Electrophysiology often shows decremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation in facial muscles more than distal limbs. Immunopathology: IgG4 anti-MuSK antibodies block MuSK phosphorylation and AChR clustering without complement activation, explaining poor response to cholinesterase inhibitors and prominent atrophy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Muscle cramps
• Incorrect: Cramps signify motor neuron hyperexcitability (e.g., ALS), not synaptic failure.
• Misconception: Equating all neuromuscular junction disorders with cramps.
• Differentiator: Cramps worsen with activity cessation; MuSK-MG weakness worsens with use.

C. Fatigue
• Incorrect: “Fatigue” is nonspecific and occurs in many neurologic/medical conditions.
• Misconception: Equating general fatigue with fatigable weakness.
• Differentiator: MuSK-MG presents with fatigable weakness confirmed by decremental EMG, not subjective fatigue alone.

D. Ptosis
• Incorrect: Ptosis/ocular signs predominate in AChR-MG, less so in MuSK-MG.
• Misconception: All MG variants present with ocular involvement.
• Differentiator: MuSK-MG often spares ocular muscles early; bulbar muscles are more severely affected.

- MuSK-MG often exhibits poor or paradoxical response to pyridostigmine; immunomodulation is cornerstone.
• Rituximab shows rapid, sustained remission in MuSK-MG (52% achieve minimal manifestation status by 6 months).
• Early bulbar atrophy may mimic ALS; always test for anti-MuSK in bulbar onset with wasted musculature.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming ocular symptoms (ptosis) are ubiquitous in all MG subtypes—MuSK-MG often spares ocular muscles.
2. Misinterpreting muscle cramps as myasthenic—cramps indicate hyperexcitability, not synaptic failure.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Myasthenia Gravis Foundation of America (MGFA) 2021 update: recommends early B-cell–depleting therapy (e.g., rituximab) for MuSK-MG due to IgG4 pathogenesis (Level B evidence).
2. European Academy of Neurology (EAN) 2017 consensus: highlights bulbar involvement and atrophy as distinguishing features of MuSK-MG; cholinesterase inhibitors are often insufficient (Level C evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

MuSK is localized at the postsynaptic membrane of the neuromuscular junction, primarily in bulbar and facial muscles where neuromuscular transmission relies on tight AChR clustering.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Anti-MuSK IgG4 antibodies block the MuSK–Lrp4 interaction, preventing AChR clustering without complement fixing—leading to synaptic transmission failure and consequent muscle weakness and atrophy.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: bulbar weakness, tongue atrophy.
2. Serology: anti-MuSK antibody assay.
3. Electrophysiology: RNS decrement in facial/bulbar muscles; SFEMG increased jitter.
4. Exclude AChR antibodies to differentiate subtype.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: immunosuppression with corticosteroids and steroid-sparing agents.
• Early rituximab indicated for refractory or bulbar-predominant MuSK-MG.
• Limited benefit from pyridostigmine; may exacerbate cramps.

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Peripheral nerve hyperexcitability (PNH) syndromes arise from continuous involuntary muscle fiber activity due to autoantibodies against voltage-gated potassium channel (VGKC) complex proteins (CASPR2, LGI1). Neuromyotonia—manifested by cramps, stiffness, and myokymia—is identified on EMG by spontaneous doublet/triplet discharges. Isaac syndrome denotes PNH confined to peripheral nerves. Morvan syndrome adds central nervous system involvement (encephalopathy, hallucinations, autonomic dysfunction, sleep disturbances) and can present with transient altered consciousness. Differentiating from stiff person syndrome (anti-GAD–mediated muscle rigidity without neuromyotonia) and multiple sclerosis (demyelinating CNS lesions, spasticity) requires synthesizing clinical, electrophysiological, serological, and imaging data to guide immunotherapy decisions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Morvan syndrome is defined by neuromyotonia plus central features. EMG in Morvan shows the same spontaneous high-frequency discharges as Isaac syndrome, but the key distinguishing factor is CNS involvement. According to the consensus criteria for autoimmune encephalitis (Graus et al., Lancet Neurol 2016;15(4):391–404, updated 2021), Morvan syndrome patients often harbor CASPR2 antibodies with encephalopathic features. Van Sonderen et al. (Neurology 2016;87:521–531) reported that 97% of clinically diagnosed Morvan syndrome patients had CASPR2 antibodies; 85% had autonomic symptoms; 60% had neuropsychiatric manifestations including transient consciousness changes. First-line treatment involves high-dose corticosteroids, IVIG or plasmapheresis (Level C evidence), followed by rituximab for refractory cases.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Isaac syndrome
• Presents with neuromyotonia but lacks central signs such as loss of consciousness.
• Misconception: Equating any neuromyotonia syndrome with Isaac syndrome; fails to consider encephalopathy.

C. Stiff person syndrome
• Characterized by axial/truncal rigidity and spasms with anti-GAD65 antibodies; EMG shows continuous motor unit activity but without high-frequency doublets/triplets.
• Misconception: Confusing muscle stiffness in both, but stiff person lacks neuromyotonia discharges and CNS LOC episodes.

D. Multiple sclerosis
• Demyelinating plaques cause spastic gait, sensory deficits, and variable consciousness; EMG does not show neuromyotonia.
• Misconception: Attributing episodic neurological deficits to MS, but ignores electrophysiology and autoantibodies.

• CASPR2 antibody titers correlate with disease severity and can guide immunotherapy response.
• Always assess for CNS features (e.g., altered consciousness, hallucinations) when EMG reveals neuromyotonia.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all PNH syndromes with Isaac syndrome, leading to missed CNS pathology in Morvan syndrome.
2. Relying solely on EMG without serological testing for VGKC-complex antibodies, delaying accurate diagnosis and immunotherapy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Graus et al., “A Clinical Approach to Autoimmune Encephalitis” (Lancet Neurol 2016; updated 2021): Recommends first-line immunotherapy (steroids/IVIG/plasma exchange) for CASPR2/LGI1 antibody syndromes (Level C).
• European Academy of Neurology (EAN) 2023 Consensus on PNH Syndromes: Advises symptomatic treatment with anticonvulsants (e.g., carbamazepine) and early immunotherapy in antibody-positive cases; rituximab for refractory patients (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

VGKC-complex proteins (CASPR2, LGI1) localize at juxtaparanodal regions of peripheral motor axons and in hippocampal/cortical interneurons, explaining combined peripheral hyperexcitability and central encephalopathy.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoantibodies against CASPR2 disrupt VGKC function, increasing neuronal excitability peripherally (neuromyotonia) and centrally (encephalopathy). Complement activation and receptor internalization further exacerbate symptoms.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: stiffness + muscle twitching ± CNS symptoms
2. EMG: confirm neuromyotonia (doublet/triplet discharges)
3. Serology: test for VGKC-complex antibodies (CASPR2, LGI1)
4. CNS evaluation: MRI, EEG if encephalopathy suspected
5. Initiate immunotherapy based on antibody status and severity

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Symptomatic: carbamazepine or phenytoin to reduce peripheral discharges.
• Immunotherapy: high-dose corticosteroids, IVIG or plasmapheresis first-line; rituximab or cyclophosphamide for refractory disease.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Paramyotonia congenita is a non-dystrophic skeletal muscle sodium channelopathy. Key concepts:
• Voltage-gated sodium channel (SCN4A) mutations alter inactivation kinetics, causing sustained depolarization.
• “Paradoxical” myotonia: stiffness worsens with cold or continued muscle use (unlike classic warm-up in other myotonias).
• Clinical hallmark: cold- or exercise-induced eyelid or hand muscle stiffness, lasting minutes to hours and sometimes followed by transient weakness.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Paramyotonia congenita is confirmed by cold-provoked myotonia on electromyography (EMG) and SCN4A genetic testing. Finkel et al. (Neurology 2020) demonstrated that cold exposure prolongs sodium channel open time in mutant fibers, producing sustained action potentials. The AAN 2023 practice guideline on muscle channelopathies (Level B evidence) endorses EMG with cold-stimulation protocols for diagnosis and recommends mexiletine as first-line therapy. European Neuromuscular Centre (ENMC) Consensus (2021; Level C) underscores avoidance of cold triggers and use of sodium channel blockers (mexiletine, lamotrigine) for symptom control.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Myotonic dystrophy
• Incorrect because DM1/DM2 feature multisystem involvement (cataracts, cardiac conduction block, endocrine issues) and a warm-up phenomenon (improved stiffness with continued exercise), not cold-aggravated eyelid stiffness.

C. Hypokalemic periodic paralysis
• Presents with episodic flaccid weakness triggered by carbohydrate-rich meals or rest after exercise, without myotonia. Serum K+ is low during attacks; eyelid myotonia is absent.

D. Congenital myasthenic syndrome
• Manifests as fatigable weakness, ptosis, and bulbar symptoms from neuromuscular junction defects, not true myotonia or cold sensitivity. EMG shows decremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation.

• Genetic confirmation via SCN4A sequencing clarifies prognosis and guides family counseling.
• Mexiletine (200–300 mg TID) reduces myotonic discharges by stabilizing the inactivated state of sodium channels; monitor ECG for QT prolongation.

1. Mistaking cold-induced stiffness for Raynaud’s phenomenon or arthritis rather than a channelopathy.
2. Confusing paramyotonia congenita with myotonic dystrophy due to both having “myotonia” in the name; DM features systemic signs and a warm-up effect.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Guideline on Muscle Channelopathies, 2023: Recommends EMG cold-stimulation protocol (Level B) and mexiletine as first-line therapy (Level B).
• ENMC International Workshop on Non-dystrophic Myotonias Consensus, 2021: Advises avoidance of cold and use of sodium channel blockers (mexiletine, lamotrigine) based on expert consensus (Level C).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

SCN4A mutations impair fast inactivation of the Nav1.4 channel, causing repetitive action potentials and myotonic discharges. Cold temperatures further slow inactivation, amplifying membrane hyperexcitability and paradoxical stiffness.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: cold/exercise-induced stiffness, duration, distribution.
2. Physical exam: eyelid and hand myotonia; percussion myotonia.
3. EMG: myotonic discharges at room temperature, prolonged potentials with cold-stimulation protocol.
4. Genetic testing: SCN4A gene sequencing for definitive diagnosis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Mexiletine: 200–300 mg every 8 hours; monitor cardiac status.
• Alternatives: lamotrigine, ranolazine in mexiletine-intolerant patients.
• Avoid cold exposure; pre-warm environment before activity.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is characterized by combined upper and lower motor neuron degeneration. Key concepts:
• Motor neuron involvement: progressive loss of anterior horn cells (LMN signs: weakness, atrophy, fasciculations) and corticospinal tract neurons (UMN signs: hyperreflexia, spasticity).
• Focal onset: patients may present with isolated limb weakness (e.g., brachial amyotrophic diplegia) before spreading.
• Treatment goal: disease modification—no cure exists; pharmacotherapy aims to slow progression.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Riluzole is a glutamate-release inhibitor shown in randomized, placebo-controlled trials (Bensimon et al., 1994; Lacomblez et al., 1996) to extend survival by ~2–3 months and delay tracheostomy. The 2020 AAN Practice Guidelines (Level B evidence) recommend initiating riluzole at 50 mg twice daily as soon as ALS is diagnosed. Edaravone (radical scavenger) may be added in early-stage patients but is not first-line monotherapy in classic limb-onset ALS. No immunomodulatory therapies have shown benefit in ALS, supporting riluzole as the most appropriate disease-modifying agent.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. IVIG
• Why incorrect: ALS is neurodegenerative, not autoimmune; IVIG benefits inflammatory neuropathies (e.g., CIDP).
• Misconception: treating fasciculations and weakness with immunotherapy.
• Differentiator: IVIG modulates autoantibodies; ALS pathology lacks autoantibody-mediated demyelination.

C. Prednisolone
• Why incorrect: Steroids are effective in inflammatory myopathies/myasthenia gravis but not in ALS.
• Misconception: all progressive motor neuron disorders respond to immunosuppression.
• Differentiator: ALS shows no inflammatory infiltrates amenable to steroids.

D. Plasma exchange
• Why incorrect: Plasma exchange treats antibody-mediated disorders (e.g., Guillain-Barré syndrome), not ALS.
• Misconception: any LMN syndrome benefits from removal of circulating factors.
• Differentiator: ALS pathology is intrinsic motor neuron degeneration without pathogenic plasma factors.

- Initiate riluzole promptly; early treatment correlates with maximal survival benefit.
• Monitor liver function tests every 3 months due to hepatotoxicity risk.
• Consider edaravone in early-stage ALS patients (ambulatory, FVC >80%), per 2017 FDA label.

1. Assuming fasciculations imply immune-mediated neuropathy—ALS is degenerative.
2. Believing steroids or IVIG slow ALS progression—no clinical trial support.

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2020: “Riluzole should be offered to all ALS patients (Level B).”
• European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS) 2018: “Riluzole recommended; edaravone considered for early-stage ALS (Level II).”

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration affects anterior horn cells (leading to muscle atrophy, fasciculations) and corticospinal tracts (eventually causing spasticity), though early limb-onset cases may lack UMN signs.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Glutamate-mediated excitotoxicity contributes to motor neuron death; riluzole modulates this by inhibiting glutamate release and inactivating sodium channels.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion (LMN + UMN signs)
2. EMG: widespread denervation and reinnervation
3. Exclude mimics (MRI spine/brain to rule out compressive lesions)
4. Confirm El Escorial criteria
5. Initiate riluzole therapy

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI of brain and cervical spine is typically normal in ALS but is essential to exclude structural myelopathies or intracranial lesions.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Riluzole dosing: 50 mg PO twice daily. Monitor LFTs at baseline, then quarterly. Common side effects: asthenia, nausea, hepatic enzyme elevation.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Periodic paralysis comprises a group of channelopathies characterized by episodic muscle weakness due to transient shifts in serum potassium.
1. Muscle membrane excitability depends on the resting membrane potential, primarily set by the potassium gradient across the sarcolemma.
2. In hypokalemic periodic paralysis (most common in Asians, including Filipinos), an acute intracellular shift of K⁺ leads to membrane hyperpolarization and flaccid paralysis.
3. Thyrotoxic periodic paralysis is a subset where excess thyroid hormone induces Na⁺/K⁺‐ATPase overactivity, precipitating acute hypokalemia. Rapid differentiation from other neuromuscular causes hinges on timely electrolyte assessment.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The single most critical immediate test in suspected periodic paralysis is a serum potassium concentration:
• Acute hypokalemia (<3.0 mmol/L) confirms the pathophysiological basis of weakness and directs therapy (IV or oral potassium).
• Delayed measurement can normalize as the attack resolves, leading to misdiagnosis.
Clinical guidelines (see below) uniformly recommend immediate K⁺ measurement before more specialized tests. EMG may show decreased amplitude but is non‐specific and often normal between attacks. Thyroid function tests are important in recurrent attacks but are secondary; acute management demands correction of K⁺. Serum calcium does not acutely fluctuate in periodic paralysis and will not guide urgent therapy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Thyroid function tests
• Incorrect: While thyrotoxicosis can cause periodic paralysis, TSH/T4 assays take hours and do not guide emergent correction of hypokalemia.
• Misconception: Equating thyrotoxic periodic paralysis with primary hyperthyroidism work‐up; acute weakness must be stratified by K⁺ first.

C. Electromyography (EMG)
• Incorrect: EMG findings (reduced CMAP amplitudes during attack) are supportive but non‐specific; normal between episodes. Not first‐line for acute weakness.
• Misconception: Overvaluing electrophysiology in initial emergency evaluation rather than simple blood tests.

D. Serum calcium level
• Incorrect: Calcium remains normal in periodic paralysis; hypocalcemia presents with tetany, cramping, not flaccid weakness.
• Misconception: Generalizing all electrolyte disturbances as potential causes of acute weakness without distinguishing clinical patterns.

Clinical Pearls

- In Asian males with acute flaccid paralysis, always check K⁺ first—>90% of thyrotoxic periodic paralysis occur in this demographic.
• During an attack, frequent low‐dose oral K⁺ (10–20 mmol) is preferred over large boluses to avoid rebound hyperkalemia.
• Between attacks, consider beta‐blockers (e.g., propranolol) in thyrotoxic periodic paralysis to reduce Na⁺/K⁺‐ATPase activity.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering EMG or nerve conduction studies before electrolytes can delay life‐saving potassium replacement.
2. Missing thyrotoxic periodic paralysis by only measuring K⁺ and forgetting to check thyroid function during follow‐up.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Thyroid Association, “Management Guidelines for Hyperthyroidism and Other Causes of Thyrotoxicosis” (2016):
• Recommendation: In patients of Asian descent with acute muscle weakness, measure serum K⁺ immediately to diagnose thyrotoxic periodic paralysis (Grade C, expert consensus).
2. European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS), “Guidelines on the Diagnosis and Management of Muscle Channelopathies” (2018):
• Recommendation: Initial evaluation of suspected periodic paralysis should include serum electrolytes (K⁺, Na⁺) prior to EMG or genetic testing (Level B, cohort studies).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: episodic flaccid weakness, precipitating factors (carbohydrate load, rest after exercise).
2. Immediate labs: serum K⁺, Na⁺, glucose.
3. If K⁺ <3.0 mmol/L, initiate controlled potassium replacement.
4. Once stabilized, obtain thyroid function tests.
5. For recurrent attacks, perform EMG with long exercise test and consider genetic testing (CACNA1S, SCN4A mutations).

[Exam: Part II 2019] Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute, immune-mediated demyelinating polyneuropathy targeting peripheral motor nerves, including the phrenic nerve (C3–C5), which controls diaphragmatic contraction. Demyelination and conduction block lead to rapid muscle weakness and risk of respiratory failure. Monitoring the forced vital capacity (FVC) and negative inspiratory force (NIF) provides direct, quantitative assessment of diaphragmatic and intercostal muscle function. Secondary assessments include the Medical Research Council (MRC) sum score for limb strength and autonomic parameters (heart rate variability, blood pressure), but these do not reliably predict ventilatory compromise. Early detection of declining respiratory capacity is critical to guide timely intubation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Respiratory function testing is the single strongest predictor of impending ventilatory failure in GBS. The European Federation of Neurological Societies/Peripheral Nerve Society (EFNS/PNS) guidelines (2010; reaffirmed 2021) recommend measuring FVC and NIF at baseline and every 4–6 hours in patients with bulbar signs or FVC <50% predicted. Walgaard et al. (2010) demonstrated that an FVC <20 mL/kg has 85% sensitivity for predicting respiratory insufficiency. The American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Advisory (2022) advises hourly FVC monitoring when values decline below 50% predicted; intubation is indicated when FVC falls under 20 mL/kg. In contrast, MRC sum scores and autonomic indices lag behind diaphragmatic weakness and have lower predictive value for respiratory failure.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Muscle strength
– Although the MRC sum score (0–60) gauges limb weakness severity and correlates with overall prognosis, it does not directly measure diaphragmatic function; phrenic nerve involvement may precede overt limb weakness.
– Misconception: equating limb motor scores with respiratory capacity.

B. Autonomic function
– Monitoring heart rate variability and arrhythmias identifies dysautonomia (e.g., labile BP, bradyarrhythmias) but does not assess neuromuscular respiratory compromise.
– Misconception: assuming cardiovascular metrics reflect ventilatory status.

C. Blood pressure
– Frequent BP readings detect autonomic instability (hypotension/hypertension) but do not inform on respiratory muscle strength or ventilatory reserve.
– Misconception: believing hemodynamic stability excludes risk of respiratory failure.

Clinical Pearls

- An FVC decline below 20 mL/kg signals imminent ventilatory failure; prepare for endotracheal intubation.
• Serial MRC sum scores quantify limb weakness but cannot substitute for respiratory function tests.
• Continuous ECG and BP monitoring are vital to detect life-threatening dysautonomia in GBS.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overreliance on limb muscle scores: Normal MRC scores can mask diaphragmatic weakness, delaying intervention.
2. Equating stable BP with overall stability: Patients may develop hypoventilation despite normotension or hypertension.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- EFNS/PNS Guideline Update (European Federation of Neurological Societies/Peripheral Nerve Society, 2021):
• FVC and NIF should be measured at baseline and every 4–6 hours in patients with bulbar signs or FVC < 50% predicted (Level B).
• Intubation recommended when FVC < 20 mL/kg (Level B).
• AAN Practice Advisory for GBS Management (American Academy of Neurology, 2022):
• Hourly FVC monitoring when FVC < 50% predicted; intubate at FVC < 20 mL/kg (Level C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The phrenic nerve, originating from C3–C5 ventral roots, innervates the diaphragm. Demyelination in GBS disrupts phrenic axonal conduction, reducing diaphragmatic excursion and FVC.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoantibodies against peripheral nerve gangliosides activate complement, leading to segmental demyelination and conduction block. Motor fibers to respiratory muscles are particularly vulnerable, precipitating hypoventilation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize ascending, symmetric flaccid paralysis with areflexia.
2. Obtain baseline FVC and NIF.
3. Perform CSF analysis—look for albuminocytologic dissociation.
4. Conduct nerve conduction studies—identify demyelination and conduction block.
5. Monitor respiratory function serially to guide ventilatory support.

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Limb‐girdle muscular dystrophies (LGMD) feature predominantly proximal muscle weakness affecting the pelvic and shoulder girdles. Classification hinges on inheritance: LGMD2 denotes autosomal recessive, LGMD1 autosomal dominant. Scapular winging reflects periscapular muscle involvement (serratus anterior, trapezius); its presence without facial weakness narrows differential. Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy (FSHD) is autosomal dominant with prominent facial weakness and scapular winging. Calpainopathy (LGMD2A) arises from CAPN3 mutations leading to protease deficiency, typically presenting in young adults with symmetric proximal weakness and scapular winging but spared facial muscles. Muscle fiber necrosis, regeneration, and elevated creatine kinase (often >10× normal) are hallmarks. Understanding genotype–phenotype correlation and inheritance patterns is essential for accurate diagnosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

LGMD2A (calpainopathy) is correct based on clinical presentation, inheritance, imaging, and genetic data. Onset is usually in the second to third decade with symmetric shoulder and pelvic girdle weakness and bilateral scapular winging; facial muscles remain unaffected. CAPN3 encodes the calcium‐dependent protease calpain‐3; pathogenic mutations cause defective sarcomeric remodeling. The 2nd ENMC International Workshop on LGMD Classification (Straub et al., Ann Neurol 2018) recommends CAPN3 gene sequencing as first‐line testing in autosomal recessive LGMD (Consensus Level D). Muscle MRI typically shows fatty infiltration of adductor magnus and hamstrings (Pichiecchio et al., Radiology 2018). Preclinical AAV‐mediated CAPN3 gene therapy restores muscle function in Capn3–/– mice (Amburgey et al., Mol Ther 2019), confirming its causative role. EMG demonstrates myopathic units; CK levels often exceed 2,000 IU/L. Genetic confirmation guides prognosis and genetic counseling.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. LGMD1B
• Inheritance: autosomal dominant LMNA mutations; often presents with early cardiac conduction defects and atrioventricular block.
• Misconception: grouping all LGMD together; key discriminator is dominant transmission and prominent cardiac involvement.

C. FSHD
• Inheritance: autosomal dominant contraction of D4Z4 repeats on chromosome 4q35; hallmark is facial weakness and asymmetric scapular winging.
• Misconception: scapular winging only in LGMD; FSHD always includes facial asymmetry early.

D. LGMD2C
• Inheritance: autosomal recessive SGCG mutations; childhood onset, pseudohypertrophy, more severe contractures, and early cardiomyopathy.
• Misconception: all AR LGMD subtypes present in adulthood; sarcoglycanopathies generally manifest earlier with cardiac involvement.

Clinical Pearls

- Scapular winging with facial sparing in a young adult and AR pedigree is highly suggestive of calpainopathy (LGMD2A).
• CK levels in LGMD2A commonly exceed 2,000 IU/L—marked elevation should prompt CAPN3 genetic testing.
• Muscle MRI pattern recognition (adductor magnus, hamstrings) can streamline targeted gene analysis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming scapular winging always indicates FSHD, leading to misdiagnosis when facial muscles are intact.
• Ignoring inheritance patterns; conflating autosomal dominant and recessive LGMD subtypes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. ENMC 2nd Workshop on LGMD Classification (Ann Neurol 2018;84:725–733): Consensus (Level D) recommends CAPN3 sequencing as first‐line in suspected AR LGMD.
2. AANEM Practice Parameter for Genetic Testing in Adult‐Onset Neuromuscular Disorders (Muscle Nerve 2021;63:7–33): Level B evidence endorses NGS panels including CAPN3 for LGMD diagnosis.
3. Amburgey et al., Mol Ther 2019;27:1282–1293: Preclinical AAV‐mediated CAPN3 gene therapy in Capn3–/– mice restored calpain‐3 expression and improved muscle strength, supporting gene‐based interventions.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Calpain‐3 is a skeletal muscle‐specific, calcium‐activated cysteine protease localized to the sarcomeric N2A region. It modulates sarcomere integrity by cleaving substrates (titin, filamin C) during muscle fiber remodeling. CAPN3 loss‐of‐function mutations impair proteolytic turnover, leading to accumulation of damaged cytoskeletal proteins, recurrent fiber necrosis, and inefficient regeneration.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: proximal girdle weakness, scapular winging, facial sparing, AR family history.
2. Laboratory: measure CK (often >2,000 IU/L).
3. EMG: myopathic motor unit potentials.
4. Muscle MRI: selective adipose infiltration of posterior thigh muscles.
5. Genetic testing: CAPN3 sequencing or LGMD NGS panel.
6. Muscle biopsy (if genetics inconclusive): evaluate calpain‐3 on immunohistochemistry and western blot.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Early fatty infiltration in adductor magnus, semimembranosus, and biceps femoris is characteristic of LGMD2A.
• Relative sparing of sartorius and gracilis aids differentiation from sarcoglycanopathies.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Progressive sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy over ≥8 weeks suggests an acquired demyelinating process rather than acute (Guillain-Barré) or purely motor disorders. Key principles:
• Peripheral nerve myelin (Schwann cells) ensures saltatory conduction; demyelination slows velocity and causes conduction block.
• Sensory involvement (tingling, numbness) plus motor weakness and areflexia localizes to a mixed neuropathy.
• Time course >8 weeks defines chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) versus acute variants.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CIDP is an immune‐mediated demyelinating neuropathy characterized by symmetric, proximal and distal weakness with sensory loss and areflexia over ≥8 weeks. The 2021 European Academy of Neurology/Peripheral Nerve Society guidelines define diagnostic criteria based on electrodiagnostic evidence of demyelination (slowed conduction velocity, prolonged distal latencies, conduction block), elevated CSF protein without pleocytosis (“albuminocytologic dissociation”), and response to immunotherapy. In this patient, the initial 3-month progression followed by stabilization and superimposed focal foot drop aligns with a CIDP variant (Lewis–Sumner syndrome). Randomized controlled trials (e.g., ICE trial, 2008) demonstrate that IV immunoglobulin (IVIG) yields significant functional improvement (level I evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome
• Incorrect: Presents with proximal muscle weakness, autonomic dysfunction, and facilitation on repetitive nerve stimulation; sensory nerves are spared.
• Misconception: Any weakness with areflexia = neuromuscular junction disorder.
• Differentiator: LEMS shows incremental CMAP amplitude after exercise, not sensory symptoms.

C. Multifocal Motor Neuropathy (MMN)
• Incorrect: Purely motor neuropathy with conduction blocks in motor nerves; no sensory loss or paresthesias.
• Misconception: Foot drop with asymmetric weakness implies MMN.
• Differentiator: Absence of sensory signs and anti-GM1 antibodies; responds to IVIG but lacks sensory involvement.

D. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
• Incorrect: Mixed upper and lower motor neuron signs, preserved sensation, often hyperreflexia.
• Misconception: Progressive limb weakness always suggests motor neuron disease.
• Differentiator: ALS exhibits normal nerve conduction velocities and no CSF albuminocytologic dissociation.

• CSF albuminocytologic dissociation is seen in ~90% of CIDP cases but may be normal early.
• First-line therapy: corticosteroids (1 mg/kg/day prednisolone), IVIG (2 g/kg over 2–5 days), or plasmapheresis; choice guided by comorbidities.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing foot drop as L5 radiculopathy—check for sensory level and generalized areflexia.
2. Confusing MMN with CIDP—always assess for sensory symptoms and CSF protein elevation.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- European Academy of Neurology/PNS CIDP Guidelines (2021): Recommend electrodiagnostic criteria for demyelination and first‐line immunotherapy (IVIG or steroids). (Level A)
• ICE Trial (Randomized Controlled Trial, 2008): Demonstrated significant functional improvement with IVIG vs placebo in CIDP (level I evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Demyelination targets Schwann-cell–derived myelin in peripheral nerves, disrupting saltatory conduction across nodes of Ranvier and leading to slowed conduction velocity and conduction block on nerve studies.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoimmune-mediated macrophage and complement activation against peripheral nerve myelin triggers segmental demyelination, endoneurial inflammation, and secondary axonal loss over time.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: symmetric vs asymmetric, sensory involvement, reflexes.
2. Electrodiagnostic testing: assess conduction velocity, F-waves, CMAP amplitudes.
3. CSF analysis: elevated protein without pleocytosis.
4. Exclude mimics: blood tests for diabetes, autoimmune panels, nerve biopsy if uncertain.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Corticosteroids: Prednisolone 1 mg/kg/day with slow taper over months.
• IVIG: 2 g/kg divided over 2–5 days; maintenance 1 g/kg every 3–6 weeks.
• Plasmapheresis: 4–6 exchanges over 2 weeks for severe cases.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by CTG repeat expansion in the DMPK gene. It is characterized by electrical myotonia on EMG, progressive muscle weakness, multisystem involvement (cataracts, endocrine dysfunction, cardiac conduction defects) and respiratory compromise due to diaphragmatic/intercostal weakness. Cerebral aneurysms have been reported, likely reflecting small‐vessel abnormalities in DM1. Electrical myotonia—waxing and waning discharges on EMG—may occur even when clinical myotonia (grip/percussion myotonia) is absent. The underlying pathophysiology involves toxic CUG RNA gain‐of‐function, sequestering muscleblind‐like proteins (MBNL), leading to aberrant splicing (notably of CLCN1) and membrane hyperexcitability. Early recognition via EMG and confirmatory molecular testing for CTG expansions is critical for management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Myotonic dystrophy is the only listed condition combining respiratory failure, cerebral aneurysm association and electrical myotonia.
• The American Association of Neuromuscular and Electrodiagnostic Medicine (AANEM) 2019 consensus (Level B evidence) stipulates EMG‐demonstrated myotonic discharges as diagnostic, followed by genetic confirmation of CTG repeat expansion in DMPK.
• The European Reference Network for Rare Neuromuscular Diseases (ERN‐RND) 2020 position statement (Level C) recommends brain MRA screening in DM1 for aneurysm detection.
• The Wave Trial (Ruscello et al., 2020) was a randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled study (Level I evidence) demonstrating that mexiletine 200 mg TID significantly reduces both electrical and clinical myotonia in DM1.
In contrast, Pompe disease (acid α-glucosidase deficiency) and Duchenne dystrophy are myopathies without myotonic discharges, and ALS shows neurogenic potentials without myotonia or vascular abnormalities.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Pompe disease
• Incorrect: Glycogen accumulation in acid α-glucosidase deficiency causes myopathic EMG potentials but no myotonic discharges or aneurysms.
• Misconception: Respiratory failure suggests Pompe but absence of EMG myotonia and CTG repeat expansion rules it out.

C. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
• Incorrect: ALS produces fibrillations, positive sharp waves and fasciculations on EMG, not myotonic discharges. No predilection for cerebral aneurysms.
• Misconception: Combined LMN/UMN signs and respiratory failure may mimic DM1, but EMG and genetics differentiate.

D. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
• Incorrect: X-linked dystrophinopathy with childhood onset, elevated CK, myopathic EMG but no myotonia. Cerebral aneurysms are not a feature.
• Misconception: Muscle weakness in a young male is suggestive, but age of onset and EMG pattern differ.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking myotonic discharges for fasciculations or repetitive fibrillations on EMG.
• Attributing respiratory failure solely to primary pulmonary pathology without considering neuromuscular causes.
• Overlooking multisystem signs (cataracts, endocrine abnormalities) that point toward DM1 rather than isolated myopathy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Association of Neuromuscular and Electrodiagnostic Medicine (AANEM) Consensus Guidelines on Myotonic Dystrophy, 2019: EMG demonstration of myotonia plus genetic CTG repeat testing is required for diagnosis (Level B evidence).
2. European Reference Network for Rare Neuromuscular Diseases (ERN‐RND) Position Statement, 2020: Recommends routine brain MRA screening for aneurysms in DM1 (Level C evidence).
3. Wave Trial (Ruscello et al.), 2020: Randomized, placebo‐controlled study showing mexiletine 200 mg TID significantly reduces myotonic discharges and improves functional myotonia in DM1 (Level I evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Membrane hyperexcitability in DM1 arises from defective chloride conductance in skeletal muscle fibers due to mis-splicing of the CLCN1 transcript; cerebral small‐vessel abnormalities underlie aneurysm formation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

CTG repeat expansions in the DMPK gene produce toxic CUG RNA, sequestering MBNL proteins and altering splicing of multiple pre-mRNAs (notably CLCN1), leading to reduced chloride channel expression and membrane hyperexcitability manifesting as myotonia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: family history, cataracts, endocrine/cardiac signs.
2. EMG: detect electrical myotonia.
3. Genetic testing: quantify CTG repeat expansion in DMPK.
4. Multidisciplinary management: neurology, pulmonology, cardiology, genetics.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Brain MRI in DM1 may show periventricular white matter hyperintensities; MR angiography can detect asymptomatic intracranial aneurysms.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First‐line: mexiletine (sodium channel blocker) 150–200 mg TID to reduce myotonia. Alternatives: lamotrigine 50–100 mg daily or ranolazine for refractory cases.

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Paramyotonia congenita is a non-dystrophic myotonia caused by SCN4A sodium channel mutations. Core principles:
• Voltage-gated sodium channel inactivation kinetics determine muscle fiber excitability.
• Cold temperatures enhance slow inactivation of mutant Na⁺ channels, leading to paradoxical myotonia and CMAP decrement.
• Electrophysiological testing (short and long exercise tests) under cold stress is diagnostic, demonstrating >40% CMAP amplitude drop.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Cold exposure in paramyotonia congenita increases slow inactivation of defective Nav1.4 channels, reducing available sodium conductance on repetitive stimulation. Watanabe et al. (2004) localized SCN4A mutations that accentuate cold-induced inactivation. Fournier and Matthews (2015) standardized the long exercise test: a ≥40% CMAP amplitude decrement after cold challenge confirms diagnosis. The American Academy of Neurology Practice Parameter (2012) endorses cold-exercise EMG protocols (Level B evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Increases
• Why incorrect: Cold promotes channel inactivation, not enhanced excitability.
• Misconception: Thinking cold stiffening equals increased action potential size.
• Differentiator: True warm-up phenomenon (myotonia congenita) increases amplitude, not cold.

C. Remains unchanged
• Why incorrect: Mutant channels exhibit temperature-dependent gating; amplitude does change.
• Misconception: Assuming uniform response across channelopathies.
• Differentiator: Normokalemic periodic paralysis shows unchanged CMAP, not paramyotonia.

D. Fluctuates
• Why incorrect: The decrement is progressive and sustained, not random.
• Misconception: Belief that cold induces variable block rather than cumulative inactivation.
• Differentiator: “Fluctuation” implies irregular pattern; paramyotonia shows predictable decrement.

• Mutations in the voltage sensor domain (S4) of Nav1.4 often underlie severe cold sensitivity.
• Differentiating paramyotonia from myotonia congenita hinges on cold versus warm provocation tests.

1. Confusing paramyotonia with Becker’s myotonia (warm-up positive)—students may omit cold challenge.
2. Overlooking the ≥40% CMAP decrement criterion, leading to false negatives in EMG interpretation.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology Practice Parameter (2012)
• Recommendation: Use both short and long exercise EMG tests, including cold exposure, for non-dystrophic myotonia (Level B evidence).
2. EFNS/ENS Consensus on Channelopathies (European Journal of Neurology, 2018)
• Recommendation: Genetic testing for SCN4A mutations in suspected paramyotonia; cold-exercise testing refines phenotype-genotype correlation (Level C evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

SCN4A mutations slow fast inactivation and enhance entry into slow inactivated states at low temperatures. Reduced sodium current causes action potential failure on repetitive stimulation, manifesting as CMAP amplitude decrement.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: cold-induced muscle stiffness, paradoxical myotonia.
2. Serum electrolytes: rule out periodic paralysis.
3. Short and long exercise EMG at room and 15°C: quantify CMAP changes.
4. Genetic testing for SCN4A variants if EMG shows ≥40% decrement.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line: Mexiletine 150–200 mg TID—blocks persistent sodium current and reduces myotonia. Monitor ECG for QT prolongation. Alternative: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide) in mexiletine-intolerant patients.
