[Exam: Part 1 2020] Distal myopathies are hereditary muscle diseases where weakness begins in the distal limb muscles rather than the proximal girdles.
Dysferlin, encoded by the DYSF gene, is a sarcolemmal protein critical for membrane repair; its deficiency leads to myofiber necrosis and elevated CK.
Clinical patterns—posterior calf (gastrocnemius/soleus) involvement with CK often >3000 U/L—distinguish Miyoshi myopathy from other distal or generalized myopathies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Miyoshi myopathy is a dysferlinopathy presenting in late teens to early adulthood with initial weakness of the gastrocnemius and soleus. CK levels typically range 2000–20 000 U/L.
AAN guidelines (2020) recommend NGS panels including DYSF for distal myopathies (Level A).
Krahn et al. (Muscle Nerve 2010) demonstrated that dysferlin deficiency on Western blot correlates with clinical Miyoshi phenotype.
Muscle MRI shows selective fatty infiltration of posterior calf muscles, helping differentiate from tibialis anterior–predominant Nonaka myopathy (GNE mutation).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Nemaline myopathy
 • Onset in infancy/childhood with hypotonia, facial weakness and rod inclusions on biopsy.
 • CK is normal or mildly elevated (<500 U/L).
 • Misconception: all myopathies present with high CK—nemaline often does not.

C. Nonaka myopathy
 • Also distal, but initially affects anterior tibialis causing foot drop; muscle biopsy shows rimmed vacuoles.
 • Caused by GNE mutation; CK moderately elevated (~1000–3000 U/L).
 • Key differentiator: pattern of weakness (anterior vs posterior compartment).

D. Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy
 • Proximal pelvic and shoulder girdle weakness; late calf involvement possible but not initial.
 • Genetic heterogeneity (e.g., CAPN3, FKRP) and phenotype is predominantly proximal.
 • Misconception: high CK alone suggests LGMD—distribution is critical.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• EFNS Task Force on Genetic Muscle Disorders (2014): recommends NGS panels after EMG and MRI for distal myopathies (Level B).
• AAN Practice Guideline on Genetic Testing in Neuromuscular Disorders (2020): endorses multigene NGS as first-line for suspected dysferlinopathy (Level A).
• REPAIR Phase I/II gene therapy trial for dysferlin deficiency (NCT03489962, 2023) shows safety and preliminary muscle strength improvement.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Dysferlin mediates calcium-dependent resealing of sarcolemmal tears during muscle contraction. Loss of function leads to ongoing fiber necrosis, macrophage infiltration, and replacement by fat and connective tissue.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical exam: confirm distal calf weakness.
2. Serum CK: expect >2000 U/L.
3. EMG: myopathic potentials.
4. Muscle MRI: posterior calf fatty infiltration.
5. Muscle biopsy: absent dysferlin on immunostaining.
6. Genetic testing: DYSF gene sequencing.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Muscle MRI in Miyoshi shows selective fatty replacement of gastrocnemius and soleus with sparing of anterior compartment early in disease.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No disease-modifying drugs currently; management is supportive (physical therapy, orthoses). Gene therapy trials are ongoing.

[Exam: Part II 2019] - Idiopathic inflammatory myopathies (IIMs) include dermatomyositis (DM), polymyositis (PM) and inclusion-body myositis (IBM).
• DM is characterized by a complement-mediated microangiopathy targeting perimysial and perifascicular capillaries, leading to muscle fiber ischemia and atrophy.
• Histopathology: perivascular and perifascicular inflammatory infiltrates (primarily CD4+ T cells, B cells, plasmacytoid dendritic cells) with complement (C5b-9) deposition distinguishes DM from PM (endomysial, CD8+ T cell–mediated) and IBM (endomysial inflammation plus rimmed vacuoles).

(Word count: 102)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Perifascicular (perivascular) inflammation and atrophy in DM were first described by Bohan & Peter (1975) and corroborated by subsequent electron-microscopic studies showing C5b-9 deposition on endomysial capillaries (Dalakas et al., Neurology 1993). The ACR/EULAR 2017 classification criteria for IIM assign high weight to perifascicular atrophy on biopsy (Ann Rheum Dis 2017;76:1955). Complement activation leads to capillary necrosis, muscle fiber ischemia, and upregulation of interferon-inducible genes in perifascicular regions (Greenberg et al., Nat Med 2005). This microangiopathic process underlies the pathognomonic histological pattern in DM.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Rimmed vacuoles
• Seen in IBM, not DM; represent intracytoplasmic aggregates of misfolded proteins.
• Common misconception: associating any vacuolar change with inflammatory myopathies.
• Differentiator: IBM has both rimmed vacuoles and endomysial CD8+ infiltration.

C. Endomysial inflammation
• Characteristic of PM, where CD8+ T cells invade non‐necrotic muscle fibers.
• Misconception: assuming all IIMs have diffuse endomysial infiltrates.
• In DM inflammation is perimysial/perivascular, sparing endomysium.

D. Neurogenic atrophy
• Occurs in peripheral neuropathies (e.g., ALS, CIDP), with angular fibers and group atrophy.
• Mistaken identity: misapplying neuropathic patterns to myopathies.
• DM shows perifascicular fiber atrophy, not angular atrophy.

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is characterized by progressive degeneration of upper motor neurons in the motor cortex and lower motor neurons in the brainstem and spinal cord. Approximately 10% of ALS cases are familial, following Mendelian inheritance, most often autosomal dominant. Key pathogenic mechanisms include toxic gain-of-function protein aggregation, RNA dysregulation, and impaired clearance of misfolded proteins. Genetic mutations drive distinct molecular cascades: hexanucleotide repeat expansions in C9orf72 lead to RNA foci and dipeptide repeat protein toxicity; SOD1 mutations cause misfolded enzyme aggregation; TDP-43 (encoded by TARDBP) and FUS mutations disrupt RNA binding and nuclear export. Familiarity with relative gene frequencies and mechanisms is essential for targeted genetic testing and emerging gene-directed therapies.
(Word count: 135)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The C9orf72 gene harbors a GGGGCC hexanucleotide repeat expansion and accounts for ~40% of familial ALS, making it by far the most prevalent genetic cause (DeJesus-Hernandez et al., Neuron 2011; Renton et al., Neuron 2011). This expansion produces RNA foci that sequester RNA-binding proteins and undergo repeat-associated non-ATG (RAN) translation into dipeptide repeat proteins, triggering neurotoxicity and nucleocytoplasmic transport defects. Current AAN (American Academy of Neurology) practice parameters (2022) recommend C9orf72 testing as first-line in all familial ALS cases (Level B evidence). By contrast, SOD1 mutations account for 15–20% of familial ALS, TARDBP for ~4%, and FUS for ~4%. The high yield and direct implications for emerging antisense oligonucleotide (ASO) trials (e.g., BIIB078 for C9orf72) underscore its primacy in diagnostics and research.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. SOD1
– Incorrect because SOD1 mutations represent the second most common cause (~15–20%), not the most.
– Misconception: Early research emphasized SOD1 due to its 1993 discovery.
– Differentiator: Missense mutations in SOD1 lead to misfolded enzyme aggregates rather than repeat expansions.

B. TARDBP
– Incorrect; TARDBP mutations account for ~4% of familial ALS.
– Misconception: Equating TDP-43 pathology in sporadic ALS with TARDBP gene frequency.
– Differentiator: TARDBP mutations affect RNA-binding protein localization, not repeat expansions.

C. FUS
– Incorrect; FUS mutations also account for ~4% of familial cases.
– Misconception: FUS proteinopathy prominence in frontotemporal dementia conflated with frequency in ALS.
– Differentiator: FUS mutations alter DNA/RNA binding and nuclear import signals rather than generating dipeptide repeats.

– Always initiate genetic testing with C9orf72 repeat-expansion analysis in familial ALS due to highest diagnostic yield.
– Genetic counseling is mandatory before and after testing to discuss inheritance risk and psychosocial impact.
– C9orf72 expansions also confer risk for frontotemporal dementia; monitor cognitive and behavioral changes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming SOD1 is most common because it was discovered first.
2. Equating pathological TDP-43 inclusions in sporadic ALS with TARDBP mutation frequency.
3. Neglecting to test for C9orf72 in apparently sporadic cases with bulbar onset or family history of FTD.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

– American Academy of Neurology (2022): Recommends C9orf72 testing for all familial ALS cases (Level B).
– European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS, 2021): Advocates C9orf72 analysis as first-line genetic test; SOD1 second.
– BIIB078 Phase 1/2 (2024): ASO targeting C9orf72 hexanucleotide repeats demonstrated dose-dependent reduction in dipeptide repeat proteins in CSF (NCT03626012).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration affects Betz cells in primary motor cortex (upper motor neurons) and α-motor neurons in anterior horn of spinal cord (lower motor neurons), correlating with spasticity and muscle weakness.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

C9orf72 expansions cause both toxic gain-of-function (RNA foci, dipeptide repeats) and loss-of-function (reduced C9orf72 protein), disrupting autophagy, nucleocytoplasmic transport, and stress granule dynamics.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: UMN & LMN signs in multiple regions
2. Electromyography: confirms denervation
3. MRI brain/spine: exclude mimics
4. Genetic testing: C9orf72 → SOD1 → panel for TARDBP, FUS, others

Pharmacotherapy Focus

– Riluzole (50 mg bid) modestly prolongs survival via glutamate release inhibition.
– Edaravone (60 mg IV daily ×14 days) may slow functional decline by free radical scavenging.
– ASOs for C9orf72 (BIIB078) and SOD1 (tofersen) under investigation.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Skeletal muscle excitability depends on voltage‐gated ion channels: Na⁺ channels initiate action potentials, while Cl⁻, K⁺ and Ca²⁺ channels regulate repolarization. Myotonia is delayed muscle relaxation caused by membrane hyperexcitability. Nondystrophic myotonias manifest with percussion myotonia and action myotonia. Paramyotonia congenita (SCN4A mutation) features paradoxical myotonia that worsens with exercise and cold, often with eyelid myotonia and forced eye closure on sneezing. In contrast, myotonia congenita (CLCN1 mutation) exhibits a “warm‐up” phenomenon, with stiffness improving on repeated activity.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Paramyotonia congenita is caused by gain-of-function mutations in SCN4A, encoding the skeletal muscle Naᵥ1.4 channel. Defective fast inactivation leads to a persistent inward Na⁺ current, prolonging depolarization and triggering repetitive discharges (myotonic runs) on EMG. Clinically, stiffness is induced and paradoxically worsened by exercise or cold, and eyelid myotonia (“eyes stuck shut”) is characteristic. This contrasts with CLCN1 mutations in myotonia congenita, where Cl⁻ channel loss-of-function causes hyperexcitability but displays a warm‐up effect. Statland et al. (N Engl J Med 2012) conducted a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial demonstrating that mexiletine (200–600 mg daily) reduces myotonic stiffness (Level I evidence). The 2017 EAN/EFNS guidelines recommend mexiletine as first-line therapy for nondystrophic myotonia (Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Potassium channel
• K⁺ channel mutations (e.g., KCNJ2 in Andersen-Tawil syndrome) cause periodic paralysis, arrhythmias and dysmorphic features, not myotonia.
• Misconception: Confusing episodic weakness disorders with myotonic stiffness.
• Key differentiation: Periodic paralysis presents with transient weakness, lacks percussion or eyelid myotonia.

C. Calcium channel
• CACNA1S mutations cause hypokalemic periodic paralysis, characterized by episodic flaccid weakness precipitated by carbohydrate load or rest.
• Misconception: Assuming muscle stiffness arises from Ca²⁺ channel dysfunction.
• Key differentiation: No delayed relaxation or paradoxical exercise-induced stiffness.

D. Chloride channel
• CLCN1 mutations underlie myotonia congenita, which shows a warm-up phenomenon (stiffness improves with repeated contractions), not paradoxical worsening with exercise or cold.
• Misconception: Attributing all myotonia to Cl⁻ channel defects.
• Key differentiation: Warm-up vs paradoxical myotonia and absence of cold sensitivity.

Clinical Pearls

- Eyelid myotonia and “eyes frozen shut” on sneezing strongly suggest paramyotonia congenita.
• Distinguish paradoxical myotonia (worsening with exercise/cold) from warm-up phenomenon (improvement with exercise).
• Percussion myotonia over the thenar eminence and EMG myotonic discharges guide diagnosis; confirm with genetic testing (SCN4A vs CLCN1).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all myotonic disorders to chloride channel mutations without recognizing exercise-induced exacerbation in sodium channelopathies.
2. Mislabeling periodic paralysis (weakness) as myotonia due to hyperkalemia.
3. Overlooking eyelid myotonia, leading to misdiagnosis as stiff-person syndrome or dystonia.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Statland JM et al. “Efficacy of mexiletine in myotonia congenita and paramyotonia congenita: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.” N Engl J Med. 2012;366:110–117. Recommendation: Mexiletine reduces myotonic stiffness; Level I evidence.
• EAN/EFNS Guidelines for Skeletal Muscle Channelopathies. Eur J Neurol. 2017;24:1079–1088. Recommendation: Sodium channel blockers (e.g., mexiletine) as first-line symptomatic therapy; Level B evidence.
• Consensus Recommendations for Genetic Testing in Inherited Neuromuscular Channelopathies. Neurology. 2018;90(10):473–482. Recommendation: SCN4A sequencing for exercise-induced myotonia; Level B evidence.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

SCN4A gain-of-function mutations impair fast inactivation of Naᵥ1.4 channels, increasing persistent Na⁺ influx. Sustained depolarization triggers repetitive action potentials (myotonic discharges) and clinical muscle stiffness, particularly under cold or during continued activity, which further destabilizes inactivation kinetics.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: identify triggers (exercise, cold), note eyelid myotonia and sneezing-induced eye closure.
2. Exam: percussion myotonia, eyelid lid lag.
3. EMG: myotonic discharges with waxing–waning frequency.
4. Labs: serum K⁺ typically normal.
5. Genetic testing: SCN4A and CLCN1 panel to confirm subtype.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Mexiletine (200–600 mg/day in divided doses) stabilizes the inactivated state of Naᵥ1.4 channels, reducing persistent current and alleviating myotonia. Monitor for gastrointestinal side effects, cardiac conduction changes (ECG recommended). Alternatives: lamotrigine, ranolazine or flecainide in refractory cases.

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM) is an inflammatory myopathy characterized by slowly progressive, asymmetric weakness (especially finger flexors and quadriceps) with rimmed vacuoles and protein aggregates on muscle biopsy.
Immune-mediated muscle fiber degeneration in IBM is refractory to conventional immunosuppression, distinguishing it from polymyositis and dermatomyositis.
Management focuses on multidisciplinary supportive measures—exercise, assistive devices, occupational therapy—to maintain function and minimize complications.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Supportive care is the cornerstone of IBM management because multiple randomized and observational studies have demonstrated lack of sustained benefit from corticosteroids or other immunosuppressants.
• AAN Practice Guideline (2016) concluded “insufficient evidence to recommend steroids or immunosuppressive agents in IBM” (Level C evidence).
• ENMC International Workshop on IBM Treatment (2021) reaffirmed that “no disease‐modifying therapy is proven; physical and occupational therapies form the mainstay” (expert consensus).
Progressive resistance exercise programs yield modest gains in strength and function (J Neurol 2019;266:2999–3007), but these remain part of comprehensive supportive care rather than standalone “cures.”

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Prednisone
• Why incorrect: IBM muscle fibers show resistance to glucocorticoids; short‐term CK decreases do not translate into functional gains.
• Misconception: IBM is a steroid‐responsive inflammatory myopathy like polymyositis.
C. Physical therapy
• Why incorrect: While critical, physical therapy alone is one component; “supportive care” encompasses PT plus orthoses, exercise guidance, fall prevention and nutrition.
• Misconception: Equating a single modality with the full management plan.
D. Immunosuppressants
• Why incorrect: Trials of methotrexate, azathioprine, IVIg and other agents have failed to show durable benefit.
• Misconception: All inflammatory myopathies respond to immunosuppression.

Clinical Pearls

• IBM often presents after age 50 with finger flexor and quadriceps weakness—resistant to steroids.
• Progressive resistance exercise can slow functional decline but does not alter disease progression.
• Early referral to physical and occupational therapy reduces fall risk and preserves independence.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating IBM like polymyositis with high‐dose steroids—fails to improve strength and exposes patients to side effects.
2. Monitoring CK levels to gauge treatment response—CK may fluctuate independently of clinical function in IBM.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AAN Practice Guideline on IIM (Neurology 2016): Insufficient evidence for steroids or immunosuppressants in IBM (Level C).
2. ENMC International Workshop on IBM Treatment (J Neuromuscul Dis 2021): Expert consensus endorses supportive care (physical therapy, orthoses) as primary management.
3. Xia et al., J Neurol 2019;266:2999–3007: Progressive resistance training showed statistically significant improvement in 6‐minute walk and grip strength (Level II evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

IBM involves both autoaggressive CD8+ T cell–mediated myonuclear invasion and degenerative processes with β‐amyloid and phosphorylated tau aggregates. Proteasome dysfunction contributes to rimmed vacuole formation, explaining poor response to immunosuppression.

[Exam: Part II 2018] - Demyelination in AIDP affects the myelin sheath of peripheral nerves, slowing conduction velocity and prolonging latencies.
• F-waves test proximal nerve segments (nerve roots and proximal plexus); early demyelination here prolongs or abolishes F-wave responses.
• Conduction block, temporal dispersion, and CMAP amplitude reduction reflect more extensive segmental demyelination or secondary axonal loss, which typically appear later.

(Word count: 86)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The earliest electrophysiological marker in AIDP is an abnormality of F-waves—specifically prolonged minimal F-wave latencies or absent F-waves—even when distal motor latencies and CMAP amplitudes remain within normal limits. Multiple studies (Uncini et al., 2003; Chiò et al., 2003) demonstrate that proximal demyelination at the nerve roots leads to delayed back-firing of motor neurons, detectable as F-wave changes within the first 24–48 hours of symptom onset. In contrast, conduction block and temporal dispersion require sufficient segmental demyelination along a nerve trunk to manifest, typically after day 3–5. Reduced CMAP amplitude signals axonal involvement or severe demyelination and often correlates with worse prognosis but emerges later (Hadden et al., 1998). Current EFNS/PNS guidelines (van den Bergh et al., 2010) recommend assessing F-waves in the initial study when GBS is suspected.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Conduction block
• Incorrect because conduction block requires focal, segmental demyelination along the nerve, which develops after initial proximal myelin injury.
• Misconception: students often equate any drop in CMAP amplitude with conduction block, but true conduction block is region-specific and appears later.
• Differentiator: conduction block is detected by comparing proximal versus distal CMAP area; not an early marker.

C. Temporal dispersion
• Incorrect: temporal dispersion (increased CMAP duration) reflects asynchronous conduction across demyelinated segments, which accumulates over days.
• Misconception: believing any widening of waveform is earliest; in reality, temporal dispersion lags behind proximal F-wave changes.
• Differentiator: CMAP duration prolongation requires multiple demyelinated internodes in series.

D. Reduced CMAP amplitude
• Incorrect: a drop in distal CMAP amplitude usually indicates axonal loss or severe demyelination of distal segments, not the earliest change.
• Misconception: amplitude loss is equated with “conduction abnormality” broadly; the first abnormality is latency-based (F-wave).
• Differentiator: amplitude reduction correlates with axonal degeneration and takes days to manifest.

Clinical Pearls

- Always include F-wave studies in the initial NCS when GBS is suspected, even if routine distal studies are normal.
• Albuminocytologic dissociation in CSF often appears after the first week; don’t delay NCS pending CSF results.
• Early detection of F-wave abnormalities can expedite immunotherapy (IVIG or plasmapheresis), improving outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming reduced CMAP amplitude is the first NCS abnormality: overlooks the proximal latency changes measured by F-waves.
2. Misinterpreting temporal dispersion as conduction block: although both reflect demyelination, dispersion is waveform broadening, block is amplitude drop on proximal vs. distal stimulation.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- EFNS/PNS Guideline (van den Bergh et al., 2010): Strong recommendation (Level A) to perform comprehensive NCS including F-waves within 2 weeks of GBS onset for accurate subtype classification.
• American Academy of Neurology Practice Advisory (2019): Recommends early electrophysiological diagnosis to guide prompt initiation of IVIG or plasma exchange; notes F-wave abnormalities often precede other NCS changes (Level B evidence).

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS) most commonly presents as acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP). Key principles:
• Peripheral nerve anatomy: motor and sensory axons myelinated by Schwann cells are targeted.
• Pathophysiology: antecedent infections (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni) trigger molecular mimicry against gangliosides (GM1, GD1a), activating complement and macrophage‐mediated demyelination at the nodes of Ranvier.
• Clinical features: symmetric, ascending weakness with areflexia and distal paresthesias; CSF shows albuminocytologic dissociation (elevated protein, normal cell count) after the first week.
• Time course: monophasic progression over days to four weeks distinguishes AIDP from chronic or central demyelinating disorders.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy accounts for ~90% of GBS cases in Europe/North America (Willison et al., NEJM 2016). The 2019 American Academy of Neurology (AAN) guideline (Level A evidence) recommends early treatment with either IVIG (0.4 g/kg/day for 5 days) or plasmapheresis (4–6 exchanges) within four weeks of symptom onset to accelerate functional recovery and reduce mechanical ventilation rates. Electrophysiology demonstrates prolonged distal latencies, slowed conduction velocities, conduction block, and temporal dispersion. CSF analysis typically shows protein >45 mg/dL with <10 cells/mm³. The antecedent diarrheal illness, particularly due to C. jejuni, is strongly associated with anti‐GM1 antibodies and an AIDP phenotype, confirming the diagnosis and distinguishing it from CIDP (chronic course), MS (CNS demyelination on MRI), and MG (neuromuscular junction defect).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP)
• Presents with progressive or relapsing symptoms over >8 weeks, not the acute monophasic onset seen here.
• Misconception: any demyelinating neuropathy is an acute GBS.
• Differentiator: CIDP often improves with corticosteroids; AIDP does not.

C. Multiple sclerosis
• A central demyelinating disease with optic neuritis, internuclear ophthalmoplegia, and MRI brain/spinal lesions plus CSF oligoclonal bands.
• Misconception: confusing central and peripheral demyelination.
• Differentiator: normal peripheral NCS in MS; abnormal in AIDP.

D. Myasthenia gravis
• A disorder of the neuromuscular junction causing fatigable weakness (ocular/bulbar) without sensory deficits or CSF protein elevation.
• Misconception: attributing proximal weakness to MG without sensory involvement.
• Differentiator: decremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation and positive acetylcholine receptor antibodies.

Clinical Pearls

- Campylobacter jejuni triggers ~30% of GBS cases; stool cultures can confirm epidemiology in hospitalized patients.
• Albuminocytologic dissociation often appears after day 4; a normal early CSF does not exclude diagnosis—repeat if suspicion remains high.
• Time to nadir (<4 weeks) is key: progression beyond 8 weeks suggests CIDP, which alters both prognosis and treatment (corticosteroids effective).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking CIDP for acute GBS when symptoms extend past 4 weeks; always track time to peak weakness.
2. Confusing sensory paresthesia in GBS with central sensory lesions in MS; perform nerve conduction studies to localize pathology.
3. Attributing symmetrical weakness solely to myasthenia gravis without evaluating reflexes or sensory involvement.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2019 Practice Guideline: Level A evidence supports IVIG or plasmapheresis within four weeks of GBS onset; corticosteroids are not recommended (Level B).
• European Academy of Neurology (EAN)/Peripheral Nerve Society (PNS) 2022 Guidelines: advocate early, multidisciplinary rehabilitation to improve long-term function and reduce hospitalization (Level B).
• International GBS Outcome Study (IGOS) 2021: early IVIG (<7 days) correlates with faster recovery milestones (observational cohort, p < 0.01).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

AIDP primarily involves demyelination of large myelinated Aα and Aβ fibers in peripheral nerves and nerve roots. Ventral root pathology produces motor weakness; dorsal root involvement yields sensory disturbances.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Molecular mimicry between C. jejuni lipooligosaccharides and peripheral nerve gangliosides (e.g., GM1) triggers complement activation and macrophage‐mediated stripping of myelin segments, causing conduction block; Schwann cell remyelination underlies monophasic recovery.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: symmetric, ascending weakness with areflexia post-infection
2. CSF analysis: albuminocytologic dissociation (>45 mg/dL protein, <10 cells/mm³)
3. NCS/EMG: demyelinating features (prolonged latencies, conduction block)
4. Exclude mimics (Lyme, HIV, toxins)
5. Immediate initiation of IVIG or plasmapheresis

Neuroimaging Pearls

Spinal MRI with gadolinium can demonstrate anterior nerve root enhancement in ~30% of AIDP cases, supporting diagnosis if electrophysiology is equivocal.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- IVIG (0.4 g/kg/day ×5 days): modulates Fc receptors, neutralizes pathogenic antibodies.
• Plasmapheresis (4–6 sessions): removes circulating autoantibodies.
• Corticosteroids: shown ineffective in acute AIDP and may delay recovery.

[Exam: Part 1 2021] • Brachial plexus organization: roots (C5–T1) form trunks (upper, middle, lower), divisions, cords, and terminal nerves.
• Sensory innervation: medial brachial cutaneous (inner arm) and medial antebrachial cutaneous (inner forearm) derive from C8–T1 roots via the lower trunk/medial cord.
• Motor innervation: thenar muscles (opponens pollicis, abductor pollicis brevis) are supplied by the recurrent branch of the median nerve, carrying fibers from C8–T1.
• Dynamic compression (e.g., costoclavicular syndrome) can produce pain on arm elevation targeting the lower trunk region.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The constellation of medial arm/forearm paresthesias, median-nerve–mediated thenar weakness, and arm-raising–induced pain localizes to the C8–T1 segment, specifically the lower trunk or medial cord of the brachial plexus. Anatomical studies (Chamberlain et al., Clin Anat 2017) confirm that the medial antebrachial cutaneous nerve arises from the medial cord carrying pure C8–T1 fibers, and median nerve motor fibers to thenar muscles also trace back to these roots. Electrodiagnostic guidelines from AANEM (2016) recommend targeted sensory nerve conduction of the medial antebrachial cutaneous nerve and EMG of C8–T1–innervated muscles to confirm lower plexus lesions. High-resolution ultrasound research (Tagliafico et al., J Ultrasound Med 2021) demonstrated >90% sensitivity for detecting hypoechoic enlargement of lower trunk fascicles in symptomatic patients.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. C7, C8
• C7 involvement yields deficits in the dorsal web space between thumb and index (radial nerve distribution) and triceps strength—absent here.
• Misconception: assuming overlap of C8 with C7; fails to account for pure T1 sensory component.
C. C5-C6
• Innervates lateral shoulder/arm (axillary, musculocutaneous distributions) and biceps reflex; does not cover medial arm/forearm or thenar muscles.
• Represents upper plexus lesions (e.g., Erb’s palsy) with deltoid/biceps weakness and lateral forearm sensory loss.
D. T1-T2
• T2 root contributes to intercostal and chest wall sensation, not upper limb median nerve or medial arm cutaneous innervation.
• Common error: overextending T1 dermatome into forearm; T2 is not involved in thenar muscle function.

• Overlooking dynamic compression; attributing symptoms solely to cervical radiculopathy without provocative testing.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] At the neuromuscular junction, acetylcholine released from the presynaptic terminal binds nicotinic receptors on the postsynaptic membrane, triggering endplate potentials and muscle contraction. Congenital myasthenic syndromes (CMS) are inherited disorders affecting distinct NMJ components: presynaptic (e.g., choline acetyltransferase deficiency), synaptic basal lamina (end-plate acetylcholinesterase deficiency), and postsynaptic (e.g., slow-channel syndrome, Dok-7 CMS). Slow-channel CMS arises from gain-of-function mutations in AChR subunits, causing prolonged channel openings, endplate myopathy, and a characteristic pattern of combined proximal limb and distal hand weakness. Differentiation of CMS subtypes relies on clinical distribution, repetitive nerve stimulation studies (showing repetitive CMAPs in slow-channel and AChE deficiency), and genetic confirmation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Slow-channel CMS is due to dominant mutations in AChR subunit genes (CHRNE, CHRNA1, CHRNB1, CHRND) leading to prolonged channel opening and Ca²⁺ overload at the motor endplate (Engel et al., Brain 2015). Clinically, these patients present with insidious, progressive weakness of both proximal limbs and distal hand muscles, and neck flexors. Electrophysiologically, low-frequency (2–3 Hz) RNS shows decrement plus repetitive CMAPs, reflecting prolonged channel activation. Open-channel blockers (quinidine, fluoxetine) alleviate symptoms by shortening channel open time (Sine & Ohno, Nat Rev Neurol 2020). Current ENMC 2020 consensus recommends against cholinesterase inhibitors in slow-channel CMS due to risk of exacerbating endplate currents (Level C evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. End-plate acetylcholinesterase deficiency
– Caused by autosomal recessive COLQ mutations leading to AChE absence; presents with fatigable weakness, often facial/bulbar involvement, and repetitive CMAPs on RNS. Differentiated by dramatic response to AChE inhibitors (unlike slow-channel where these worsen symptoms).

C. Dok-7 myasthenia
– Autosomal recessive DOK7 mutations cause limb-girdle (proximal) weakness with minimal ocular/bulbar signs; distal hand muscles are typically spared early. RNS shows decrement without repetitive CMAPs; therapy includes β2-agonists (albuterol).

D. Choline acetyltransferase deficiency
– Presynaptic CHAT mutations present in neonates/infants with episodic apnea, generalized weakness; EMG shows reduced quantal release but normal RNS recovery; hand-specific involvement is not a feature.

1. Mistaking Dok-7 for slow-channel: distal (hand) involvement and repetitive CMAPs favor slow-channel.
2. Assuming all CMS improve with AChE inhibitors: slow-channel CMS can worsen due to prolonged channel opening.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. ENMC International Workshop on CMS Management, 2020: Consensus recommends targeted genetic testing and use of open-channel blockers for slow-channel CMS; advises against cholinesterase inhibitors in this subtype (Expert Opinion, Level C).
2. American Academy of Neurology Practice Guideline on Neuromuscular Junction Disorders, 2023: Strong recommendation for RNS (2–3 Hz) and single-fiber EMG to subtype CMS and guide therapy (Level B).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Slow-channel CMS involves gain-of-function AChR mutations → prolonged opening of postsynaptic channels → excessive Ca²⁺ influx → endplate structural damage and progressive weakness.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: fatigable weakness with both proximal limb and distal hand involvement.
2. Electrophysiology: RNS at 2–3 Hz (decrement + repetitive CMAPs), single-fiber EMG (increased jitter).
3. Genetic testing: CMS panel including CHRNE, CHRNA1, CHRNB1, CHRND.
4. Initiate therapy: quinidine or fluoxetine for slow-channel CMS.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Quinidine: 200 mg TID, monitor ECG for QT prolongation.
• Fluoxetine: 20–40 mg/day, off-label use as AChR open-channel blocker.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] - Wallerian degeneration begins within 24–72 hours after axonal injury; distal CMAP amplitudes fall by day 3–5 as axons degenerate.
• Needle EMG (distinct from NCS) assesses motor unit potential recruitment during voluntary contraction; decreased recruitment reflects loss of functioning motor units.
• Denervation potentials (fibrillations) require muscle membrane instability and appear no sooner than 7–10 days post-injury; complex repetitive discharges emerge later with chronic reinnervation.
(128 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Decreased recruitment on EMG—manifesting as reduced interference pattern during voluntary contraction—is the earliest sign of axonal loss visible by day 5. Although the question states “NCS,” the parameter “recruitment” is derived from needle EMG evaluation of motor unit activation. The American Association of Neuromuscular & Electrodiagnostic Medicine (AANEM) 2021 Practice Parameter for Electrodiagnostic Evaluation of Polyneuropathy (Level C evidence) notes that CMAP amplitude reduction becomes measurable by day 3 and that motor unit recruitment deficits are apparent by days 4–7 when >50 percent of motor axons are lost. In contrast, fibrillation potentials, representing spontaneous Na⁺ channel–mediated depolarizations of denervated muscle fibers, reliably appear only after Wallerian degeneration is complete (7–21 days; Dumitru et al., Electrodiagnosis in Diseases of Nerve and Muscle, 2018). Complex repetitive discharges reflect ephaptic cross-talk in partially reinnervated fibers and arise weeks to months later. Conduction block is a hallmark of segmental demyelination, not acute axonal injury.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Fibrillation
• Why incorrect: Fibrillation potentials require full muscle fiber denervation and Na⁺ channel redistribution, appearing earliest at 7–10 days.
• Misconception: Confusing spontaneous EMG activity with early axonal signs.
• Differentiator: Onset too late; detected on needle EMG, not NCS.

C. Complex repetitive discharges
• Why incorrect: Develop only with chronic partial denervation and reinnervation (weeks–months), not acutely.
• Misconception: Assuming any spontaneous EMG abnormality appears early.
• Differentiator: Reflects ephaptic transmission in reinnervated fibers.

D. Conduction block
• Why incorrect: Indicates focal segmental demyelination leading to >20 percent amplitude drop across a segment; not a feature of pure axonal injury.
• Misconception: Believing all acute neuropathies show conduction block.
• Differentiator: Seen in Guillain–Barré syndrome or entrapment neuropathies with demyelination, not acute axonal transection.

Clinical Pearls

1. In axonal neuropathies, CMAP amplitude reduction on NCS precedes EMG fibrillations; needle EMG recruitment deficits appear by day 4–7.
2. Fibrillation potentials are pathognomonic for active denervation but require 1–3 weeks to manifest.
3. Distinguish axonal from demyelinating lesions: early recruitment loss versus conduction block/temporal dispersion.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing “recruitment” (EMG) with NCS amplitude metrics—recruitment is a voluntary activation parameter.
2. Expecting fibrillations within the first week of injury; these require completed Wallerian degeneration.
3. Interpreting early amplitude drops as conduction block rather than axonal loss.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Association of Neuromuscular & Electrodiagnostic Medicine (AANEM) Practice Parameter: Electrodiagnostic Evaluation of Polyneuropathy, 2021 (Level C) – recommends assessment of CMAP amplitude by day 3–5 and needle EMG recruitment at day 4–7.
2. EFNS/PNS Guideline on Nerve Conduction Studies in Focal Neuropathies, 2020 (Level B) – defines conduction block as >20 percent CMAP amplitude drop across a segment and emphasizes distinction from axonal losses.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The ulnar nerve traverses the cubital tunnel at the elbow, carrying motor fibers to interossei and the abductor digiti minimi. Needle EMG electrodes in these muscles best detect recruitment deficits when axons degenerate distal to the lesion.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Axonal injury triggers Wallerian degeneration: disintegration of axon and myelin distal to lesion, macrophage-mediated debris clearance, and subsequent muscle denervation. Denervation potentials arise only after sodium channel aggregation on muscle membranes.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical evaluation: sensory signs in ulnar distribution, weakness of grip and finger abduction.
2. NCS: measure CMAP amplitude, conduction velocity, assess for conduction block.
3. If axonal pattern suspected, schedule needle EMG day 5–7 post-injury.
4. On EMG, evaluate recruitment, spontaneous activity, motor unit potential morphology.
5. Integrate findings to distinguish axonal versus demyelinating neuropathy.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] 1. Dysferlin is a sarcolemmal protein; its deficiency (autosomal recessive DYSF mutations) causes two main phenotypes: Miyoshi myopathy (distal, calf‐predominant) and LGMD2B (proximal).
2. Creatine kinase (CK) in dystrophinopathies and dysferlinopathies can exceed 10–50× ULN, reflecting membrane fragility; inflammatory myopathies tend to have lower CK elevations.
3. Pattern of weakness (distal calf vs. proximal girdle) and age of onset (adolescence to early adulthood) help distinguish dysferlinopathy from other myopathies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dysferlinopathy (Miyoshi myopathy) classically presents in late teens to mid-30s with early involvement of gastrocnemius–soleus complex, manifesting as inability to stand on tiptoes and a “calf‐drop” gait. CK levels often reach 20–100× ULN. Muscle MRI shows selective fatty replacement of posterior calves. Genetic testing confirms biallelic DYSF mutations; Western blot/immunostaining demonstrates absent dysferlin.
By contrast, Becker muscular dystrophy (dystrophin gene, X-linked) has milder proximal weakness, pseudohypertrophy, and CK ~10–30× ULN. Inclusion body myositis occurs >50 years old, targets finger flexors/quadriceps with mild CK elevation. Limb-girdle muscular dystrophies are heterogenous but primarily proximal.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Becker muscular dystrophy
• Incorrect because involvement is predominantly proximal pelvic muscles with calf pseudohypertrophy, onset in adolescence; CK elevation is milder (10–30× ULN).
• Misconception: equating any high CK with dystrophinopathy; key differentiator is X-linked inheritance and proximal pattern.

C. Inclusion body myositis
• Incorrect age (>50 years), pattern (finger flexors, quadriceps) and CK usually <10× ULN.
• Misconception: assuming any distal weakness is IBM; IBM is inflammatory with rimmed vacuoles on biopsy.

D. Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy
• While LGMD2B is allelic with dysferlinopathy, the classic LGMD presentation is symmetric proximal weakness of shoulder/pelvic girdles; distal calf‐dominant involvement is atypical.
• Misconception: grouping all LGMD under one phenotype; LGMD2B can mimic Miyoshi but usually has earlier proximal signs.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] 1. Repeat-expansion myopathies: Disorders caused by trinucleotide expansions in muscle genes (e.g., GCG in PABPN1 for oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy).
2. Myasthenia gravis (MG) vs primary myopathies: MG shows fatigable, fluctuating weakness due to autoantibodies at the neuromuscular junction, whereas dystrophies cause progressive, fixed muscle weakness.
3. Clinical topography: Ptosis + dysphagia + proximal limb weakness in the fifth–sixth decade is classic for oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy (OPMD), not for facioscapulohumeral dystrophy or MG.

(Word count: 109)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer, GCG Repeat, refers to a pathogenic expansion of GCG trinucleotide repeats in the PABPN1 gene, which increases from the normal 10 to 12–17 repeats. This expansion produces insoluble intranuclear aggregates in muscle fibers, leading to a late-onset, progressive myopathy characterized by bilateral ptosis, dysphagia, and proximal limb weakness (Brais et al., 1998; Chartier et al., 2017). Onset is typically in the fifth–sixth decade, with steadily worsening, non-fluctuating symptoms.

• D4Z4 contraction (option B) is diagnostic for facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD), presenting with facial weakness and scapular winging, not ocular or pharyngeal involvement (Deenen et al., 2017).
• Acetylcholine receptor (AChR) and MuSK antibody testing (options C and D) diagnose subtypes of MG, which causes fatigable, variable ptosis and bulbar weakness that improve with rest or cholinesterase inhibitors; MG does not produce a fixed ptosis or progressive dysphagia resistant to edrophonium (MGFA 2016 guidelines).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. D4Z4
• D4Z4 repeat contraction on chromosome 4q35 causes FSHD, featuring facial and scapular girdle weakness with normal ocular and pharyngeal muscles.
• Misconception: All repeat-expansion disorders present with ptosis.

C. Acetylcholine receptor antibody testing
• Detects AChR autoantibodies in MG, which manifests with fatigable, diurnally varying weakness and positive edrophonium response, unlike the fixed, progressive weakness in OPMD.
• Misconception: Ptosis equates to MG.

D. Muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibody testing
• Identifies MuSK-positive MG, often with severe bulbar and respiratory involvement but with fluctuation and responsiveness to immunotherapy, not the slowly progressive, non-fluctuating course of OPMD.
• Misconception: Bulbar symptoms always indicate MG.

1. OPMD typically presents after age 50 with slowly progressive ptosis that does not improve with edrophonium or rest—distinguishing it from myasthenia gravis.
2. Family history can be subtle due to variable expressivity in autosomal dominant OPMD; always consider genetic testing in late-onset ptosis and dysphagia.
3. Management focuses on symptomatic relief (ptosis surgery, swallowing therapy); no disease-modifying therapy is yet approved.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing any adult-onset ptosis with dysphagia to myasthenia gravis and overlooking genetic myopathies.
2. Relying solely on edrophonium testing without considering fixed vs fluctuating weakness patterns.
3. Assuming all trinucleotide repeat disorders have similar clinical distributions (e.g., confusing OPMD with Kennedy disease or DM1).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Richards et al., ACMG 2015 variant interpretation guidelines: Classify PABPN1 GCG repeat expansions ≥12 as pathogenic in OPMD (Level C evidence).
2. European Neuromuscular Centre (ENMC) OPMD workshop, 2018: Recommended PABPN1 genetic testing for all patients with late-onset ptosis and dysphagia and standardized swallow evaluation protocols (Expert consensus).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Radiculopathy refers to dysfunction of a spinal nerve root, here C5–C6, leading to motor weakness in the myotomes these roots supply. Key concepts:
• Myotomes map spinal roots to muscle groups; C5–C6 strongly contributes to elbow flexion and supination.
• Peripheral nerve anatomy: C5–C6 fibers travel via the upper trunk of the brachial plexus to innervate specific muscles.
• Clinical localization uses strength testing (e.g., biceps reflex for C5–C6) to pinpoint root lesions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Biceps brachii is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve carrying C5 and C6 fibers (Moore et al., Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 8th ed). In C5–C6 radiculopathy, elbow flexion and forearm supination weaken, and the biceps reflex diminishes. The American Association of Electrodiagnostic Medicine (AANEM) guidelines (2020) recommend EMG confirmation by detecting fibrillation potentials in the biceps for suspected C5–C6 radiculopathy (Level A evidence). MRI commonly demonstrates nerve root compression at the foraminal level correlating with clinical deficits. Thus, biceps brachii involvement is the hallmark for C5–C6 root pathology.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Infraspinatus
– Although innervated by C5–C6 via the suprascapular nerve, its primary role is external shoulder rotation. Radiculopathy testing emphasizes larger muscle groups like elbow flexors for reliable clinical detection.
– Misconception: equating any C5–C6–innervated muscle as the best clinical marker.

C. Deltoid
– Innervated predominantly by C5 (axillary nerve) with minimal C6 contribution. In isolated C5–C6 radiculopathy, shoulder abduction may be preserved if C5 fibers are only partially affected.
– Key difference: deltoid strength reflects mainly C5 root integrity.

D. Triceps brachii
– Innervated by C7–C8 via the radial nerve. Elbow extension deficits point to C7–C8 pathology, not C5–C6.
– Common error: confusing proximal arm extension (triceps) with flexion (biceps).

• The biceps reflex (C5–C6) is more sensitive for upper root lesions than testing deltoid strength.
• In evaluating shoulder pathology, external rotation weakness should prompt infraspinatus testing but does not localize C6 involvement specifically.
• EMG fibrillation in the biceps confirms denervation at the C5–C6 root level when imaging is equivocal.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming infraspinatus weakness localizes exclusively to C5–C6 without considering its smaller muscle mass and less reliable clinical testing.
2. Overreliance on deltoid testing for C6 involvement; deltoid is predominantly C5, so C6 pathology may spare this muscle.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AANEM Practice Parameter (2020): Recommends EMG and nerve conduction studies for suspected cervical radiculopathy when MRI and clinical examination are inconclusive (Level A).
2. North American Spine Society Clinical Guideline (2021): Advises 6–12 weeks of conservative management (physical therapy, NSAIDs) before considering epidural steroid injections or surgery for cervical radiculopathy (Evidence Level C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

C5–C6 ventral rami converge in the upper trunk of the brachial plexus. The musculocutaneous nerve branches off here, supplying biceps brachii. Compression at the C5–C6 foramina disrupts this pathway, leading to characteristic motor deficits.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Disc herniation or spondylotic osteophytes narrow the intervertebral foramen at C5–C6, mechanically compressing the dorsal root ganglion and anterior motor fibers. Ischemia and demyelination ensue, causing segmental muscle weakness and altered reflexes.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: neck pain radiating to lateral arm, forearm.
2. Exam: assess myotomes—elbow flexion (biceps), wrist extension, reflexes.
3. Imaging: MRI cervical spine to identify root compression.
4. Electrophysiology: EMG of biceps brachii to confirm denervation.

Neuroimaging Pearls

On T2-weighted MRI, look for high-signal nerve root edema at the C5–C6 foramen and disc protrusions compressing the exiting nerve root.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line: NSAIDs and physical therapy. For refractory radiculopathic pain, consider a single transforaminal epidural steroid injection targeting C5–C6 (moderate-quality evidence).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] - The brachial plexus comprises roots (C5–T1), trunks (upper, middle, lower), divisions, cords, and terminal branches.
• The upper trunk (C5–C6) innervates key shoulder and arm muscles: deltoid via the axillary nerve, biceps via the musculocutaneous nerve, and wrist extensors via the radial nerve.
• Presentation of acute shoulder pain followed by weakness in arm and forearm muscles localizes to an upper trunk lesion.
• Common causes include idiopathic brachial neuritis (Parsonage–Turner syndrome) and traction/compression injuries focusing on the superficial upper trunk.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The upper trunk is most frequently implicated in adult brachial plexopathies. In idiopathic brachial neuritis, 60–70% of cases demonstrate selective C5–C6 involvement (van Alfen et al., Brain, 2006). Traction injuries (e.g., shoulder dystocia, motorcycle accidents) also preferentially stretch the upper trunk due to its superficial course in the posterior triangle (Moayeri et al., J Neurosurg, 2012). Clinically, deltoid (axillary nerve) and biceps (musculocutaneous nerve) weakness with preserved intrinsic hand function strongly indicate an upper trunk lesion. The 2015 AAN Practice Guideline recommends MRI neurography to confirm trunk-level pathology (Level B evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Lower trunk
• Involves C8–T1 fibers serving intrinsic hand muscles and finger flexors.
• Presents with ulnar-distribution sensory loss and hand weakness, sparing shoulder/arm muscles.
• Misconception: “lower trunk” sounds distal but does not explain proximal deficits.

C. Upper and lower trunk
• Would cause combined proximal (C5–C6) and distal (C8–T1) deficits, including hand intrinsic weakness.
• Rare in idiopathic brachial neuritis; more compatible with pan-plexus injury.

D. Brachial plexus
• Nonspecific term implying diffuse involvement of C5–T1.
• Would produce global upper limb motor and sensory loss, not the selective arm/forearm pattern described.

Clinical Pearls

- Parsonage–Turner syndrome: severe nocturnal shoulder pain that transitions to weakness over 1–2 weeks.
• EMG/NCS performed at 3–4 weeks post-onset maximizes detection of denervation in the upper trunk.
• MRI neurography can reveal hourglass constrictions in the upper trunk, guiding potential surgical intervention.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing C6 radiculopathy with upper trunk lesion—radiculopathy spares the deltoid, while upper trunk lesions involve both deltoid and biceps.
2. Selecting “brachial plexus” assumes a generalized injury; boards focus on precise trunk-level localization using specific motor and sensory maps.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology 2015 Practice Guideline: Recommends MRI neurography for precise localization of brachial plexus lesions (Level B).
• European Federation of Neurological Societies 2023 Guidelines: Suggest early corticosteroid therapy in idiopathic brachial neuritis to shorten the pain phase (Level C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The upper trunk forms in the posterior triangle from C5–C6 roots. Its anterior division gives rise to the musculocutaneous nerve (biceps, brachialis) and contributes to the median nerve; the posterior division continues as the axillary and radial nerves (deltoid, wrist extensors).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Traction or inflammatory (immune-mediated) injury disrupts the perineural blood supply (vasa nervorum) of the upper trunk, causing focal axonal degeneration. In Parsonage–Turner syndrome, perivascular inflammatory infiltrates lead to nerve swelling and demyelination.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: acute shoulder pain, radiation to arm/forearm.
2. Physical exam: test C5–C6–innervated muscles (shoulder abduction, elbow flexion, wrist extension) and sensory mapping.
3. EMG/NCS at 3–4 weeks: confirm denervation in C5–C6 distribution.
4. MRI neurography: visualize trunk lesion, exclude mass effect or root compression.
5. Lab studies: rule out inflammatory or metabolic neuropathies.

Neuroimaging Pearls

On T2-weighted MR neurography, the upper trunk appears enlarged with hyperintense signal and contrast enhancement. Look for “hourglass” constrictions indicating fascicular torsion.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute immune‐mediated polyneuropathy characterized by:
• Autoantibody‐ and complement‐mediated demyelination of peripheral nerve roots and proximal segments
• Ascending symmetric weakness, areflexia, sensory symptoms, and autonomic instability
• Albuminocytologic dissociation on cerebrospinal fluid (elevated protein, normal cell count)
Early immunomodulation reduces immune‐mediated axonal damage. First‐line therapies include intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) and plasmapheresis (PLEX). Corticosteroids and cytotoxic agents are not beneficial in classic GBS.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Plasmapheresis (PLEX)
• Although PLEX is equally effective to IVIG in GBS (AAN Level A), it is not “most effective” over IVIG; its invasiveness and hemodynamic risks make IVIG the preferred initial choice.
• Misconception: Students may think mechanical removal of antibodies is superior; evidence shows parity.

C. Corticosteroids
• Large RCTs (e.g., ACTG GBS Study Group) demonstrated no benefit—and possible delays in recovery—when high‐dose methylprednisolone was added.
• Misconception: “All immune‐mediated neuropathies respond to steroids.” GBS is an exception.

D. Cyclophosphamide
• An alkylating immunosuppressant used in vasculitic neuropathies and severe CIDP, not supported in acute GBS.
• Misconception: “Stronger immunosuppression equals better outcome.” In GBS, targeted immunomodulation (IVIG/PLEX) is optimal.

1. Initiate IVIG or PLEX within 2 weeks of onset for optimal functional recovery.
2. Monitor forced vital capacity and autonomic signs hourly in progression phase.
3. Avoid corticosteroids in GBS—unlike in CIDP, they do not accelerate recovery.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing high‐dose steroids for acute GBS—studies show no benefit and potential harm.
2. Delaying immunotherapy until advanced respiratory failure—treatment is most effective early.
3. Confusing GBS with CIDP: steroids are efficacious in CIDP but not in GBS.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology Practice Parameter Update (2011)
– Recommendation: IVIG or PLEX within 2 weeks of GBS onset (Level A); corticosteroids not beneficial (Level A).
2. Cochrane Systematic Review (2016)
– Finding: IVIG and PLEX yield equivalent outcomes in speed of recovery and long‐term disability; combination therapy offers no additional benefit.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

GBS primarily targets Schwann cell–wrapped myelin of ventral and dorsal spinal nerve roots. Demyelination leads to slowed nerve conduction and conduction block, most pronounced in proximal segments due to blood–nerve barrier permeability.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Molecular mimicry following infections (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni) triggers anti‐ganglioside (GM1, GD1a) antibodies. Complement activation and macrophage‐mediated myelin stripping cause segmental demyelination and secondary axonal injury.

The correct answer is A. IV immunoglobulin (IVIG). This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

[Exam: Part II 2019] Flaccid paralysis with areflexia and intact sensation localizes to the peripheral nervous system—specifically the anterior horn cell, peripheral nerve, neuromuscular junction, or muscle. In the postpartum period, immune modulation can precipitate acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (Guillain‐Barré syndrome, GBS). Reflex arcs involve Ia afferents, anterior horn α‐motor neurons, and efferent motor fibers; demyelination slows conduction without initially affecting sensation. Magnesium toxicity from eclampsia prophylaxis can cause neuromuscular blockade with hyporeflexia but typically shows respiratory depression and altered mental status. Differentiating these etiologies rests on targeted diagnostic tests: nerve conduction studies (NCS) detect demyelination, lumbar puncture (LP) shows albuminocytologic dissociation (often after 1 week), MRI identifies central cord pathology, and serum magnesium levels rule out iatrogenic toxicity.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Lumbar Puncture (LP)
• Why incorrect: Albuminocytologic dissociation in GBS often requires ≥7 days post‐symptom onset. Early LP may be normal, risking false reassurance.
• Misconception: Belief that LP is the definitive first test for suspected GBS.
• Differentiator: LP is useful later or when presentation is atypical (e.g., fever, severe back pain).

C. MRI of the cervical spine
• Why incorrect: Normal sensory exam and flaccid paralysis localize to peripheral nerves, not spinal cord. MRI is low‐yield and delays electrodiagnosis.
• Misconception: Ordering MRI for all paralysis without precise localization.
• Differentiator: MRI identifies structural compression or demyelinating lesions in the cord, not peripheral demyelination.

D. Magnesium level
• Why incorrect: No history of magnesium sulfate use or signs of toxicity (respiratory depression, sedation). Serum magnesium is irrelevant in typical GBS presentation.
• Misconception: Equating all hyporeflexic paralysis postpartum with magnesium toxicity.
• Differentiator: Magnesium toxicity features include depressed mental status and ventilatory drive, distinguishing it from GBS.

Clinical Pearls

1. In suspected GBS, always monitor forced vital capacity (FVC) and negative inspiratory force to anticipate respiratory failure.
2. NCS should be obtained early—even if normal, repeat at 1–2 weeks if clinical suspicion remains high.
3. Postpartum patients should be queried about magnesium sulfate exposure; absence argues against iatrogenic neuromuscular blockade.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming LP is mandatory before starting therapy in GBS—electrodiagnosis plus clinical features suffice to begin treatment.
2. Ordering MRI for hypotonic paralysis without CNS signs—peripheral versus central localization is key to efficient workup.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (2011) Practice Parameter: Recommends early NCS to confirm GBS; Level A evidence for efficacy of IVIG and plasmapheresis.
• NICE Guideline CG195 (2019): Advises immediate electrodiagnostic studies and respiratory monitoring in suspected GBS; LP reserved for atypical features.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

GBS targets peripheral myelin of motor fibers—especially large‐diameter Aα fibers in anterior roots—leading to conduction slowing, conduction block, and areflexia, while sparing small sensory fibers initially.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy involves autoantibody and complement‐mediated Schwann cell injury, segmental demyelination, and macrophage infiltration predominantly at the nodes of Ranvier.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: flaccid paralysis, areflexia, intact sensation.
2. Rule out central causes (if upper motor neuron signs).
3. Obtain NCS early to detect demyelination.
4. Monitor respiratory function continuously.
5. Initiate IVIG or plasmapheresis based on severity.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Spinal MRI in GBS may show gadolinium enhancement of nerve roots but is neither sensitive nor required for diagnosis; reserved for atypical presentations.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First‐line therapies for GBS: IVIG 0.4 g/kg/day for 5 days or 4–6 sessions of plasmapheresis; no proven benefit from corticosteroids.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Monomelic amyotrophy (Hirayama disease) is a focal lower motor neuron disorder affecting anterior horn cells at C7–T1. Key principles:
• Lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions produce muscle weakness, atrophy, fasciculations, and preserved sensation.
• “Monomelic” denotes involvement of a single limb, typically the distal upper extremity in young males.
• Dynamic flexion of the cervical spine exacerbates anterior cord compression, leading to ischemic injury of cervical anterior horn cells.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The hallmark of monomelic amyotrophy is insidious-onset, unilateral or asymmetric wasting and weakness of the distal upper limb without sensory loss. Hirayama’s landmark series (Hirayama et al., 1959) and subsequent Japanese cohort studies (Ito et al., J Neurol Sci 2006) confirm onset in adolescence/early adulthood, male predominance (~90%), and C7–T1 muscle group involvement. EMG shows chronic denervation in one arm; sensory nerve conduction is normal. Flexion MRI demonstrates forward displacement of the posterior dural sac with a crescent-shaped epidural flow void at C6–C7 (Pradhan & Sinha, Neurol India 2020). Natural history is benign; progression halts within 5 years. There are no formal pharmacologic therapies; cervical collar immobilization is recommended to prevent neck flexion and further cord injury (Japanese Spinal Cord Society Consensus 2019).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Symmetrical weakness in the lower limbs
• Incorrect: Monomelic amyotrophy is focal to one upper limb, not symmetrical lower limbs.
• Misconception: All motor neuron diseases have generalized patterns.
• Differentiation: Lower limb symmetry suggests spinal muscular atrophy or polyneuropathy, not Hirayama disease.

C. Rapidly progressive weakness with sensory loss
• Incorrect: Monomelic amyotrophy progresses slowly over years and has no sensory involvement.
• Misconception: LMN disorders always spare sensation but progress rapidly.
• Differentiation: Rapid course plus sensory signs suggest inflammatory myelopathy or CIDP.

D. Isolated sensory symptoms in the upper limbs
• Incorrect: Hirayama disease is purely motor.
• Misconception: Any focal limb syndrome must include sensory disturbances.
• Differentiation: Pure sensory symptoms point toward peripheral neuropathy or dorsal column pathology.

Clinical Pearls

1. Cold exposure often worsens hand weakness in Hirayama disease (“cold paresis”).
2. Early cervical collar use can halt progression by limiting neck flexion–induced cord compression.
3. EMG showing chronic denervation in one limb with normal sensory studies is virtually pathognomonic.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing as ALS: ALS involves both UMN and LMN signs, often generalized, and progression is relentless.
2. Overlooking dynamic MRI: A neutral MRI may be normal; imaging in neck flexion is critical to visualize dural displacement.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Japanese Spinal Cord Society Consensus (2019): Recommends cervical flexion MRI for suspected Hirayama disease to demonstrate dural forward shift (Level II evidence).
2. EFNS/PNS Lower Motor Neuron Disorders Guideline (2020): Advises conservative management with a cervical collar for early-stage monomelic amyotrophy to prevent progression (Level C evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Anterior horn cells at C7–T1 innervate hand intrinsic muscles (interossei, lumbricals) and wrist flexors; their selective ischemic injury leads to distal hand wasting.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

During neck flexion, disproportionate lengthening of the posterior dural sac causes it to shift anteriorly, compressing the cervical spinal cord and inducing chronic microcirculatory ischemia in anterior horn cells.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in young male with unilateral hand wasting
2. Nerve conduction studies (normal sensory) + EMG (denervation in C7–T1 muscles)
3. Cervical MRI in neutral and flexion positions
4. Exclude other causes (ALS, myelopathy, multifocal motor neuropathy)

Neuroimaging Pearls

Flexion MRI: Crescent-shaped, enhancing posterior epidural space; anterior shifting of dura by ≥2 mm at C6–C7.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Mononeuritis multiplex is a patchy, asymmetric neuropathy caused by infarction of individual peripheral nerves due to vasculitis of the vasa nervorum. Key points:
• Peripheral nerves receive blood from small intraneural vessels (“vasa nervorum”); vasculitic inflammation leads to focal axonal injury.
• Presents subacutely (weeks), with asymmetric sensory-motor deficits in at least two separate nerves (e.g., peroneal nerve involvement in the leg with preserved radial/ulnar function in the arm).
• Elevated inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP) and normal imaging of the CNS further support a vasculitic neuropathy over a central or demyelinating process.

(Word count: 111)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Mononeuritis multiplex is the correct diagnosis because:
• Time course: subacute (3 weeks) with asymmetric involvement of individual nerves.
• Neurophysiology: EMG shows axonal damage in the peroneal nerve; radial/ulnar sparing confirms multifocal pattern.
• Laboratory: elevated ESR indicates systemic inflammation/vasculitis.
• MRI normal: excludes central lesions or nerve root enhancement typical of CIDP/GBS.
By contrast, CIDP and GBS are demyelinating, symmetric neuropathies. EFNS/PNS guidelines (2021) emphasize using NCS patterns—axonal in vasculitic neuropathy versus demyelinating in CIDP/GBS—to guide diagnosis (Level B evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP)
 • Incorrect: CIDP is symmetric, proximal > distal, demyelinating, chronic (>8 weeks), with elevated CSF protein but normal ESR.
 • Misconception: equating any inflammatory neuropathy with CIDP ignores distribution and electrophysiology.

C. Subacute inflammatory demyelination
 • Incorrect: Not a recognized distinct clinical entity. Suggests demyelination (should produce conduction slowing/prolonged latencies) which is absent here.

D. Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS)
 • Incorrect: GBS is acute (<4 weeks), symmetric ascending paralysis with albuminocytologic dissociation. EMG would show demyelinating features; ESR is typically normal.

Clinical Pearls

- Vasculitic neuropathy often presents with painful, patchy axonal loss—pain is a red flag.
• Always check ESR/CRP in asymmetric neuropathies; a high value warrants evaluation for systemic vasculitis (e.g., ANCA panel).
• Nerve biopsy remains gold standard but is reserved for cases where diagnosis is unclear after noninvasive testing.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all inflammatory neuropathies are demyelinating—leads to misdiagnosis of CIDP instead of mononeuritis multiplex.
2. Overreliance on MRI: a normal MRI may falsely reassure against peripheral nerve pathology; peripheral nerve MRI has limited sensitivity for vasculitic changes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American College of Rheumatology (ACR) 2021 Guidelines for ANCA-Associated Vasculitis
– Recommendation: Induce remission of vasculitic neuropathy with high-dose glucocorticoids plus cyclophosphamide or rituximab (Level B).
2. European Academy of Neurology (EAN) 2022 Inflammatory Neuropathy Guidelines
– Recommendation: Use nerve conduction studies to distinguish axonal vs demyelinating neuropathies; axonal patchy involvement with elevated ESR suggests vasculitic neuropathy (Level A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The common peroneal nerve originates from L4-S2 roots, courses around the fibular neck. Infarction of its vasa nervorum causes foot drop and sensory loss in the dorsum of the foot. Radial/ulnar nerves (C5–T1) remain unaffected in mononeuritis multiplex until those individual nerves are involved.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Segmental inflammation of the vasa nervorum (small‐vessel vasculitis) causes ischemia and infarction of individual nerve fascicles, producing focal axonal degeneration and sensory-motor deficits corresponding to the affected nerve’s distribution.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical: asymmetric focal neuropathy →
2. Laboratory: ESR/CRP, ANCA, ANA →
3. Electrophysiology: NCS/EMG to confirm axonal vs demyelinating pattern →
4. Imaging: ultrasound/MRI of peripheral nerves (often normal) →
5. Tissue diagnosis: nerve or sural biopsy if noninvasive tests inconclusive →
6. Initiate immunosuppression based on severity and underlying vasculitis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line: high-dose corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone 1 mg/kg/day) plus cyclophosphamide (e.g., 2 mg/kg/day) or rituximab for induction. Maintenance with azathioprine or methotrexate. Monitor blood counts, liver/kidney function, and infection risk.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease comprises inherited peripheral neuropathies subdivided by electrophysiology into CMT1 (demyelinating) and CMT2 (axonal). In axonal neuropathies like CMT2, loss of axons leads to reduced amplitudes of compound muscle action potentials (CMAPs) and sensory nerve action potentials (SNAPs), while conduction velocities remain near normal or only mildly slowed. In contrast, demyelinating neuropathies show markedly slowed conduction velocity and prolonged latencies with relatively preserved amplitudes. Clinically, CMT2 often presents in adolescence or adulthood with distal lower-limb weakness and sensory loss, whereas CMT1 has an earlier onset. Understanding amplitude versus velocity changes on nerve conduction studies (NCS) is essential for correct classification, guiding genetic testing and management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Type 2 CMT is an axonal neuropathy: axonal loss reduces the number of functioning sensory fibers, causing a drop in SNAP amplitude (England et al., 2009; AANEM Level A). Conduction velocities in CMT2 typically exceed 40 m/s or are only mildly reduced, distinguishing them from CMT1, where velocities fall below 38 m/s due to segmental demyelination (Pareyson et al., 2022; EAN/PNS Level C). Histopathology of CMT2 (e.g., MFN2 or GJB1 mutations) shows axonal degeneration without onion-bulb formation (Hoke, Nat Rev Neurol 2018). Thus, “SNAP drop” directly reflects the pathophysiology of CMT2 and is the hallmark electrophysiological feature.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Affects upper limbs more than lower limbs
• Incorrect: CMT typically begins in the longest fibers, so distal lower limbs are affected before upper limbs.
• Misconception: Confusing proximal versus distal onset.

C. Demyelinating neuropathy
• Incorrect: Demyelination is the hallmark of CMT1, not CMT2.
• Misconception: Equating all inherited neuropathies with slowed conduction velocity.

D. Early onset sensory ataxia
• Incorrect: CMT2 often presents in adolescence/adulthood; sensory ataxia, if present, is late and mild.
• Misconception: Mixing features of Friedreich ataxia or spinocerebellar ataxias with CMT.


Clinical Pearls

1. In axonal neuropathies, a > 50% drop in SNAP amplitude correlates with loss of > 50% of sensory axons (England et al., 2009).
2. Electrophysiological classification (axonal vs demyelinating) should precede genetic testing to optimize gene panel selection and reduce costs (Sivera et al., 2018).
3. CMT2 patients may have near-normal conduction velocities despite significant clinical weakness; always evaluate both amplitude and velocity.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overemphasis on conduction velocity alone—students may miss amplitude reductions if they focus solely on slowing.
2. Assuming all hereditary neuropathies present in childhood—CMT2 can manifest later, leading to misdiagnosis as acquired neuropathy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AANEM Practice Parameter: “Evaluation of Distal Symmetric Polyneuropathy” (England JD et al., 2009; reaffirmed 2016). Recommendation: Perform comprehensive NCS including amplitude and velocity to distinguish axonal from demyelinating neuropathies (Level A evidence).
2. Peripheral Nerve Society/EAN Guidelines on Inherited Neuropathies (Pareyson D. et al., Eur J Neurol. 2022). Recommendation: Define axonal neuropathy by SNAP amplitude reduction > 30% below the lower limit of normal and use electrophysiological phenotype to guide genetic testing (Level C evidence).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Myasthenia Gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder targeting post‐synaptic acetylcholine receptors (AChR) at the neuromuscular junction, leading to fluctuating muscle weakness and fatigability. The thymus gland modulates T-cell tolerance; thymic hyperplasia or thymoma contributes to autoantibody generation. Symptomatic therapy (pyridostigmine) offers transient relief but does not alter the disease course. Immunomodulation (steroids, IVIG) and definitive management (thymectomy) address underlying autoimmunity. Adult patients <60 years with generalized AChR-positive MG and thymic hyperplasia derive long-term remission benefits from thymectomy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Thymectomy directly reduces autoantibody production by removing hyperplastic thymic tissue. The MGTX trial (Wolfe et al., NEJM 2016) randomized non-thymomatous, AChR-positive MG patients to thymectomy plus prednisone versus prednisone alone. At three years, the thymectomy arm had significantly lower prednisone requirements (p<0.01), improved quantitative MG scores, and fewer hospitalizations. The 2020 European Academy of Neurology/European Federation of Neurological Societies guidelines assign a Level A recommendation for thymectomy in generalized, AChR-positive MG under age 60. Neither IVIG nor steroids alone provide the durable immunologic remission achieved with thymectomy in this subgroup.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. IVIG
– Incorrect because IVIG is reserved for myasthenic crisis or short-term exacerbations; it does not confer long-term disease modification in stable MG with thymic hyperplasia.
C. Start steroids low and slow
– While corticosteroids are an immunosuppressive mainstay, initiating steroids does not replace the definitive benefit of thymectomy in AChR-positive MG; steroids may transiently worsen weakness (“steroid-dip”) and require careful tapering.
D. Increase pyridostigmine dose
– Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors only improve neuromuscular transmission symptomatically; dose escalation cannot address autoantibody production or thymic pathology.

Clinical Pearls

1. Thymectomy yields maximal benefit in AChR-positive MG patients younger than 60 without thymoma.
2. The “steroid-dip” is an early worsening of weakness when initiating high-dose corticosteroids—titrate slowly and monitor respiratory strength.
3. Anti-MuSK MG does not benefit from thymectomy; serology guides surgical decisions.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating symptomatic relief (pyridostigmine) with disease modification; cholinesterase inhibitors do not reduce antibody titers.
2. Using IVIG as first-line in stable, non-crisis MG; this leads to unnecessary costs and overlooks definitive surgical therapy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

– MGTX Trial (Wolfe GI et al., NEJM 2016): Demonstrated improved clinical outcomes and steroid reduction with thymectomy in non-thymomatous, generalized AChR-positive MG. (Level I evidence)
– 2020 EAN/EFNS Guidelines (Gilhus NE et al., Eur J Neurol 2020): Recommend thymectomy (Level A) for generalized AChR-positive MG in patients aged 18–60, regardless of thymoma status.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

– Pyridostigmine dosing begins at 30–60 mg every 4–6 hours; maximal dosing limited by muscarinic side effects.
– Corticosteroids (prednisone 1 mg/kg/day) require slow tapering after clinical stability to avoid myasthenic exacerbation.
– IVIG dose: 2 g/kg over 2–5 days, reserved for crisis or pre-op preparation.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Pompe disease (glycogen storage disease type II) is a lysosomal acid α-glucosidase (GAA) deficiency leading to glycogen accumulation in cardiac and skeletal muscle. Key features in the infantile form are:
• Macroglossia due to myofiber infiltration
• Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy from myocardial glycogen build-up
• Respiratory muscle weakness causing apnea and recurrent infections
Understanding lysosomal storage pathology and the impact on muscle and cardiac tissues underpins recognition of Pompe in a 2-month-old.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Infantile Pompe disease presents by 2–3 months with cardiomegaly, hypotonia, feeding difficulties, and respiratory distress. Macroglossia and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy are distinguishing. Enzyme assay confirms low GAA activity; genetic testing identifies GAA mutations. The pivotal randomized trial by Kishnani et al. (Lancet 2007;370(9606):25–32) showed alglucosidase alfa ERT significantly improved survival and reduced ventilator dependence versus historical controls. Current consensus (Muscle Nerve. 2017;56(2):187–207) recommends early initiation of ERT at 20 mg/kg biweekly and immunomodulation in CRIM-negative infants to prevent anti-drug antibodies.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Congenital Hypothyroidism
• Incorrect: While macroglossia and hypotonia occur, hypothyroidism causes bradycardia and pericardial effusion, not true hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
• Misconception: Equating all macroglossia-causing conditions with Pompe.
• Differentiator: Normal GAA levels; elevated TSH, low T4.

C. Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome
• Incorrect: Features macroglossia and organomegaly, but presents with neonatal hypoglycemia and hemihypertrophy, not cardiomyopathy.
• Misconception: Overvaluing macroglossia without cardiac involvement.
• Differentiator: Hypoglycemia, omphalocele, hemihypertrophy.

D. Congenital Myotonic Dystrophy
• Incorrect: Leads to hypotonia and respiratory issues but classically has facial muscle weakness (“fish mouth”), not macroglossia or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
• Misconception: Confusing hypotonia and respiratory distress in infants.
• Differentiator: Genetic anticipation, CTG expansion, electrodiagnostic myotonia.
